{marveilles_du_monde_desc}Livre des Diversites et Marveilles du Monde or The Book on the Diversity of the World or the Book of Miracles was written by Rusticiano from the words of the famous traveler Marco Polo. In those days, a lot of it was considered fiction, for example: stones that can be used to heat the furnace (coal), fabric that does not burn (asbestos), paper that can be exchanged for goods (money). The travel story of Marco Polo has been a success.
{marveilles_du_monde_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+1 贸易.

{mercatura}Trading practice
{mercatura_desc}La Practica della Mercatura - travel experience between Europe and China by Francesco Pegolitti, one of the first travel notes. Pegolitti described how to behave to the merchant during his travels, where to find interpreters, intermediaries and shelter, how to sell goods and make a profit. His notes were an invaluable contribution for the merchant travelers traveling to Persia and further to China.

{drm_desc}Written by Flavius ​​Vegetius Renatus back in Roman times, this work has become the most popular military textbook, a must-read for any commander who wants to comprehend the art of war strategy and combat tactics. It consists of four books that describe how to hire, train and lead infantry, conduct sieges and naval battles.

{strategikon}Strategikon of Flavius ​​Mauricius
{strategikon_desc}Usually attributed to Emperor Flavius ​​Mauricius Tiberius Augustus in the 6th century, consists of 12 sections describing the organization, supply and training of mounted troops, how to organize a militia, and a list of war crimes and punishments for them. The Strategikon is valued as one of the first manuals on the theory of army organization.
{strategikon_effects_desc}\n属性：\n+1 统帅.\n+1 to command cavalry.

{commedia}Divine Comedy
{commedia_desc}Ital. - just "Comedy", later the word Divine was added. Written by Dante Alighieri between 1308 and 1321. A well-known work of Italian and world literature. Consists of three parts. Inferno (Hell), Purgatorio (Purgatory), and Paradiso (Paradise) both describe Dante's wanderings through the three kingdoms of the world of the dead.

In addition to love lyrics, the book sounds motives of the relationship of man, God and the church.

The first part tells about the life of his parents, as his father, Digena Emir, converted to Christianity, abducted and married his mother Digena. The following describes the superhuman exploits of Digen. Like his father, he will steal the daughter of a Byzantine military leader and then marry her

{oton}1000 and 1 night
{oton_desc}Written from 800 - 900 AD, the story tells of the Persian king Shahriyar, who used to execute his wives immediately after the wedding. The daughter of his vizier, Scheherazade, decided to put an end to such 残暴. On the night of their wedding, Scheherazade began to tell the ruler a tale, but did not finish it. The king left her alive to listen to the end of the story. The next night, Scheherazade completed one tale and began the next. And so it went on for 1000 and 1 night. There are historical, love, dark and funny tales, poems, burlesque, eroticism and Islamic myths.
{oton_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 社会治安. \n+1 人民拥戴.

Canonized by His Holiness Pope Alexander III. His promise to bequeath the kingdom to the Duke of Normandy William and the subsequent ascension to the throne of Harold Godvinson led to the famous Battle of Hastings.

{Durandal}Durandal Sword
{Durandal_desc}Sword of Roland, a character of numerous medieval legends and literary works, including "Song of Roland." Forged by the blacksmith Galan (var. - blacksmith Madelger from Regensburg, Munifican). Handled by Charles the Great to his knight after taking their oath. Forged from the same iron as the sword of King Zhuoyez. In the hilt was a vault (the blood of St. Basil, the imperishable tooth of St. Peter, the vlas of Dionysius of Paris, the divine man, a fragment of the robe of the Virgin Mary).

{Colada_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+1 权威. \n+2 骑士精神. \n+1 防御.

{Tizona}Sword of Tyson
{Tizona_desc}Tizona (Spanish: Tizona) - the sword of El Sid, the national treasure of Spain. Famous for the “Song of My Side,” according to which Sid was taken as a trophy from the Moorish king Bucar who he killed. The sword, considered to be Tizona, is exhibited in the cathedral of the city of Burgos, next to the tomb of Sid. El Sida was so adored by his people and feared by the enemies that he became the legendary figure of the Reconquista. He was the ruler of Valencia from 1043 until his death, in 1099.
{Tizona_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+2 骑士精神. \n+2 进攻统帅.

{Sword_Sherbec}Sword Shcherbets
{Sword_Sherbec_desc} The sword was made in the first half of the 13th century. for Boleslav Konradovich, nicknamed the Brave. The sword got its name "shcherbets" in one of the campaigns against Russia.\n
   The sword with which the kings of Poland were crowned. This is one of the regalia of the Piast dynasty and was used at the coronation of Polish monarchs until 1764.\n
   The length of the sword is 98 cm, there is an ornament on the hilt, the blade is sharpened on both sides. The gold plates on the parts of the hilt are engraved and blackened. On the sides of the handle and on the guard there is a text in Latin.
{Sword_Sherbec_effects_desc}\n属性：\n+1 权威.\n+2 attack.\n+1 虔诚.

{seneschal_desc}His Majesty's representative and closest assistant. The Seneschal Service is His Majesty's most important service. The duties include the organization of the protection of feasts and court ceremonies, as well as the management of servants, the Seneschal sent a court. Heads the justice system. He monitors all the profits received, the royal armies were also under his command, while His Majesty commanded the army of the whole kingdom.

A necessary participant in all formal expressions of his will. It is the duty of drawing up state acts and keeping the state seal.

¬--------------------- Правители Городов

{dearmad_inverness}Earl of Inverness and \nManor of the Highlands
{dearmad_inverness_desc}Named Earl of Inverness and ruler of the northern highlands of Scotland. \n \nDescription: \nInverness is located in the north-east of Scotland at the mouth of the Ness River, which flows into the Bay of Morie Firth. The name of the city is associated with the location of the city - in Gaelic it means the mouth of the Ness River. In the VI territory, where Inverness now stands, the Pictish tribes inhabited. It is known that a stronghold of the Pictish king Bride I was located a few kilometers west of the modern city, whom about 565 the monk St. Columbus, a Christian preacher in Shotlan, visited diy.It is believed that the first Inverness castle, which was a wooden fortress, was built around 1057 by order of King Malcolm III and subsequently destroyed by King Robert Bruce. In 1214, King Wilhelm of Leo granted Inverness four charters, one of which granted him the status of a royal city. In those days, Inverness was a fairly prosperous port, the inhabitants of which were mainly engaged in fishing.
{dearmad_inverness_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+5% 贸易收入. \n-1 忠诚.
¬----------------------

{idearmad_inverness_desc}Named Emir of Inverness and ruler of the northern highlands of Scotland. \n \nDescription: \nInverness is located in the north-east of Scotland at the mouth of the Ness River, which flows into the Bay of Morie Firth. The name of the city is associated with the location of the city - in Gaelic it means the mouth of the Ness River. In the VI territory, where Inverness now stands, the Pictish tribes inhabited. It is known that a stronghold of the Pictish king Bride I was located a few kilometers west of the modern city, whom about 565 visited the monk St. Columbus, a Christian preacher in Shotla diy.It is believed that the first Inverness castle, which was a wooden fortress, was built around 1057 by order of King Malcolm III and subsequently destroyed by King Robert Bruce. In 1214, King Wilhelm of Leo granted Inverness four charters, one of which granted him the status of a royal city. In those days, Inverness was a fairly prosperous port, the inhabitants of which were mainly engaged in fishing.

{odearmad_inverness}Inverness Strategist
{odearmad_inverness_desc}Named the Inverness Strategist ruler of the highlands of Scotland. \n \nDescription: \nInverness is located in the north-east of Scotland at the mouth of the Ness River, which flows into the Morie Firth. The name of the city is associated with the location of the city - in Gaelic it means the mouth of the Ness River. In the VI territory, where Inverness now stands, the Pictish tribes inhabited. It is known that a stronghold of the Pictish king Bride I was located a few kilometers west of the modern city, whom about 565 the monk visited St. Columbus, a Christian preacher in Scottle Andia. It is believed that the first Inverness castle, which was a wooden fortress, was built around 1057 by order of King Malcolm III and was subsequently destroyed by King Robert Bruce. In 1214, King Wilhelm of Leo granted Inverness four charters, one of which granted him royal city status. In those days, Inverness was a fairly prosperous port, the inhabitants of which were mainly engaged in fishing.

{dearmad_edinburgh}Earl of Edinburgh and \nManor of the Scottish Lowlands
{dearmad_edinburgh_desc}Named Earl of Edinburgh and ruler of the Scottish Lowlands. \n \nDescription: \n638 Control over the fortress passed to the Northumbrians loyal to King Oswald. 731 Edinburgh is mentioned as part of Northumbria in the Church history of the people of the Angles. 840-850 McAlpin raids the Lothian, owned by the Northumbrians, burns Dunbar, and possibly Edinburgh. 960 Indulf Aggressor joins Edinburgh to his possessions. 1020 Malcolm II finally annexes Edinburgh to Scotland. 1074 Edinburgh lost its original meaning as a fortress and the beginning of its development as a city. The first written mention of the settlement around the fortress as a city dates back to 1124, when the Holy Cross Church was founded in Edinburgh by decree of King David I. Edinburgh began to grow rapidly in XII, when Saint David I transferred the royal court from Dunfermline to Edinburgh Castle, and after the emergence of the Scottish Parliament in the XIII Parliament, the status of the capital was finally assigned to him. The chapel, named in her honor, was soon built on the territory of the castle. 1125 David I transfers the royal court to Edinburgh Castle. 1128 David I establishes Holyrood Abbey. 1162 Edinburgh becomes the main city in Lothian, administered by a sheriff judge.
{dearmad_edinburgh_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+10% 税收. \n-1 忠诚.
¬----------------------

{king_aberdeen}Earl of Aberdeen and the \nManor of the Grapian Mountains
{king_aberdeen_desc}Named Earl of Aberdeen and ruler of the Grapian Mountains. \n \nDescription: \nThe name Aberdeen comes from the addition of the Gaelic A-bar + dun, which means elevation in the swamps. Aberdeen grew up on the site of the ancient Roman colony of Dewan. Settlement in Old Aberdeen after the decline due to the departure of the Romans was again founded in 580 by St. Mahar, a disciple of St. Columba. The mission founded by Mahar later became an independent Aberdeen bishopric. In honor of Mahar, the Gothic cathedral built from granite was consecrated (1131–1165). In 1179, Old Aberdeen received the city All rights in the 12th-14th cities were the residence of the Scottish kings. Aberdeen was the most significant city in the north-eastern part of Scotland. The main levers of trade were rich paper, cotton, linen and spinning factories, paper plants, cable factories, tanneries and cast iron factories, export , salmon, eggs, butter, pork, bread. The city of Aberdeen, in which the castle was decorated in the old days, experienced great disasters during the Scottish wars.
{king_aberdeen_effects_desc}\n属性：\n+5% 税收.\n+1 士气.\n+10% 社会治安.\n+2 人民拥戴.\n+2 个人安全.\n+1 虔诚. 
¬----------------------

{dearmad_dublin}Lord of Dublin \nLord of Ireland
{dearmad_dublin_desc}Named Lord of Dublin and ruler of Ireland. \n \nDescription: \nApproximately 140 A.D. Ptolemy mentioned the Celtic settlement, which he called Eblan Civitas. According to these reports, the village already stood on the site of modern Dublin, although the city itself and the ramparts were laid by the Scandinavians much later. So Dublin became a stronghold of the small Viking kingdom on the island. Almost a hundred years later, in 1014, at the Battle of Klontarf, the Vikings suffered a crushing defeat from the Celtic king Brian Boru. The Viking kings began to pursue a policy of alliances and agreements with local tribes, which allowed them to retain power in Over the course of three centuries, Dublin became the stronghold of the British government in Ireland in 1169, when English troops led by Henry II Plantagenet invaded the island. They quickly conquered Wexford and easily stormed Dublin. For a long time, they were absorbed by the Anglo-Norman invaders. adopting the Irish language, customs and trade. After the Anglo-Norman invasion, many of the Scandinavian descendants of the city residents left the old city. Dublin became the residence of His Grace Ireland from 1171 and quickly after olnyaetsya settlers from England and Wales.
{dearmad_dublin_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+10% 税收. \n-1 忠诚. \n+5% 社会治安. \n+1 人民拥戴.
¬----------------------

{dearmad_london}Earl of London and the Manor
{dearmad_london_desc}Named Earl of London and ruler of the eastern manors of England. \n Description: \nIn the 6th-7th centuries, the city of Lundenwick became the Saxons, which became the capital of the East Saxon kingdom. After King Essex adopted Christianity in 604. in Londinia, the chair of the bishop of the East Saxons Mellit was located and St. Paul's Cathedral was laid. In 842 and 851, Lundenwick was attacked by the Vikings. In 871, the “great pagan army” of the Vikings, who conquered half of England, wintered in London and remained in the hands until 886. Danes. In 886, Lundenwick moved to the West Saxon king Alfred the Great, who transferred this settlement to Londinius. The Anglo-Saxon king Edward the Confessor moved his residence to the western suburbs of Lundenburg, where he restored the old abbey and founded the royal Palace after the Normans won the Battle of Hastings at Westminster Abbey, the coronation of William the Conqueror took place.The new king of England confirmed the freedom of London by excluding the city from the general census of the conquered population. On the banks of the Thames, the Normans erected the Tower. moved to Westminster, and London turned into the capital of England. London is the only European capital that has not been captured by the enemy even once in the past almost 8 centuries.
{dearmad_london_effects_desc}属性： \n+10% 税收. \n+1 忠诚. \n+10% 贸易收入. \n+5% 法律. \n-5% 腐败.

{odearmad_london}London strategist and \n eastern manors 
{odearmad_london_desc}Named the Strategist of London and the ruler of the eastern manors of England. \n Description: \nIn the 6th-7th centuries, the city of Lundenwick, which became the capital of the East Saxon kingdom, was founded in the Saxons after the adoption of Christianity by King Essex Sabert in 604. in Londinia, the chair of the bishop of the East Saxons Mellit was located and St. Paul's Cathedral was laid. In 842 and 851, Lundenwick was attacked by the Vikings. In 871, the “great pagan army” of the Vikings, who conquered half of England, wintered in London and remained in the hands until 886. Danes. In 886, Lundenwick moved to the West Saxon king Alfred the Great, who transferred this settlement to Londinius. The Anglo-Saxon king Edward the Confessor moved his residence to the western suburbs of Lundenburg, where he restored the old abbey and founded the royal Palace after the Normans won the Battle of Hastings at Westminster Abbey, the coronation of William the Conqueror took place.The new king of England confirmed the freedom of London by excluding the city from the general census of the conquered population. On the banks of the Thames, the Normans erected the Tower. moved to Westminster, and London turned into the capital of England. London is the only European capital that has not been captured by the enemy even once in the past almost 8 centuries.

{dearmad_york}Earl of York and \nNorth Manor
{dearmad_york_desc}Named Earl of York and the Northern Manors of England. \n \nDescription: \nTraditional capital of the north of England, the city arose in 71 CE on the basis of the Roman fortress of Eborac. The Romans made Eborac the capital of the province of Lower Britain. Towards the end of Roman rule, in 415, the settlement was captured by the German tribe of Angles, and renamed Eoforwick. From the 6th York center of the Anglo-Saxon kingdom of Northumbria. The first bishop of York, Pauline, received his dignity in a wooden church. Pauline baptized there King Edwin Saint in 627. From 735 -residency of the Archbishop of York. The Vikings, who captured the city in 866, were renamed Jorvik, after which the city became the capital of the kingdom of the same name, located in most of Northern England. After the Normans conquered the city received its modern name. In 1068, two years after the Norman conquest, the people of York revolted. was successful, but then William the Conqueror crushed it. He immediately built two wooden fortresses on both sides of the Uz River. In XII York began to flourish due to its position as the center of an excellent trading network. York became a shopping center rum. Merchants imported fabrics, wax, paper, oats from the Netherlands and exported grain to Gascony. Grain and wool to the Netherlands. King Henry I granted the city the first charter confirming the right to trade in England and Europe.
{dearmad_york_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+10% 税收. \n+5% 贸易收入. \n+1 虔诚.

{dearmad_nottingham}Earl of Nottingham and \ncentral manors
{dearmad_nottingham_desc}Named Earl of Nottingham and the central manors of England. \n \nDescription: \nNottingham was founded by Saxon settlers around VII. In 867, it was captured by the Danish Vikings and later became one of the fortified cities. During the reign of the Anglo-Saxons, this area was part of the kingdom of Mercia. . The city came under the rule of the Saxon leader under the name “Sottingaham.” Nottingham Castle was built by William the Conqueror in XI to expose the sandstone on the Lin River. The Anglo-Saxon settlement developed into the English borough of Nottingham and housed Go Odes Palace and Courtroom. The settlement developed around the castle on the opposite hill and was a French settlement supporting the Normans in the castle. In fact, the space between them was built up as the city grew, and a few centuries later the Old Market Square became the center of Nottingham .After the return of Richard the Lionheart from the Third Crusade, the castle was occupied by supporters of Prince John, including the Sheriff of Nottingham. It was besieged by Richard and, after a brief conflict, captured. In the legends of Ro Binde Gudet Nottingham Castle becomes the scene of a confrontation between the Sheriff and the rogue hero.

{king_exeter}Earl of Exeter and the \n southwestern manor
{king_exeter_desc}Named Earl of Exeter and the southwestern manors of England. \n \nDescription: \nExeter is the main city of the English county of Devon. Before that, it was heavily fortified and consisted of narrow and curved streets. The main attraction of the city is a large cathedral, founded back in 1050, built originally in the Norman style 1112 In the early Middle Ages, Dumnonia was an independent Celtic state, but was gradually conquered by Wessex: at the end of the 6th century, the Saxons captured the territory of the present Somerset, subjugated Devon during the 9th century, and by the end of the 10th century the kingdom of Britons became a vassal of England. The remains of Cornwall’s independence were eliminated by the middle of the 11th century - there were no more Britons among the big landowners in the Doomsday Book. Since the Norman conquest of England, Devon has served as an arena of civil conflict and hostilities. According to one version, the action in the legends of King Arthur takes place in Cornwall.
{king_exeter_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+1 忠诚.

{king_cardiff}Earl of Winchester and the \nSoutheast Manor
{king_cardiff_desc}Named Earl of Winchester and the southeastern Manor of England. \n \nDescription: \nWinchester is a city from the time of the Roman Empire. King Alfred the Great declared it the capital of the Kingdom of Wessex in IX. Already in those days, the construction of the Winchester Cathedral, which was continued by the Normans. Knud the Great made Winchester the capital of all England. There lie the remains of the famous rulers Alfred and Knud the Great. The local fair was one of the largest in the country. Wool dressing has been developed in Winchester since Saxon times and has served for centuries a lot of urban economy. Winchester Castle occupies a prominent place in English history. It was built in 1067 after the Norman conquest and was periodically the seat of the royal court. Winchester Cathedral surpasses all the medieval temples of Europe by the length of its nave (170 meters). This monument of English Gothic architecture was founded in 1079 by the local bishop Valkelin. In Winchester, the medieval almshouse Saint Cross, erected in 1136, was preserved. After a fire in the middle of the XII, Winchester finally lost the political prima TVO Londonu.Mezhdu 1222-1235g.Genrih III extended the castle, adding a "Great Hall", which is a historical artifact-imitation "Round Table" of the legendary King Arthur.

{iking_cardiff}Emir of Winchester and the \nSoutheast Manor
{iking_cardiff_desc}Named Emir of Winchester and the southeastern Manor of England. \n \nDescription: \nWinchester is a city from the time of the Roman Empire. King Alfred the Great declared it the capital of the Kingdom of Wessex in IX. At that time, the construction of the Winchester Cathedral, which was continued by the Normans. Knud the Great made Winchester the capital of all England. There lie the remains of the famous rulers Alfred and Knud the Great. The local fair was one of the largest in the country. Wool dressing has been developed in Winchester since Saxon times and has served for centuries a raft of urban economy. Winchester Castle occupies a prominent place in English history. It was built in 1067 after the Norman conquest and was periodically the seat of the royal court. Winchester Cathedral surpasses all the medieval temples of Europe by the length of its nave (170 meters). This monument of English Gothic architecture was founded in 1079 by the local bishop Valkelin. In Winchester, the medieval almshouse Saint Cross, erected in 1136, was preserved. After a fire in the middle of the XII, Winchester finally lost the political prima London. Between 1222-1235, Henry III expanded the castle to add the Great Hall, which houses a historical artifact imitation of the Round Table of the legendary King Arthur.

{dearmad_caernarvon}Prince of Wales \nGraph of Carnarvorn
{dearmad_caernarvon_desc}Named Prince of Wales and Earl of Carnarvorn. \n \nDescription: \nThe first fortifications in the area where Carnarvon Castle and the city of the same name are located were built by the Romans. The name Carnarvon comes from a Roman settlement. In Welsh, the place was known as "Fortification opposite the island of Mon." After the Norman conquests in 1066, the Welsh kingdoms began to fall under the influence of their eastern neighbors. William the Conqueror tried to subdue the Welsh, creating several powerful feudal estates on the border with Wales. Some Welsh rulers, such as Owain Gwynedd, Rhys ap Grifid, Llewelyn ap Yorvert, at different times united a significant part of the country under their authority, but Wales did not completely unite. According to the Doomsday Book, Wilhelm appointed governor Welsh Robert Rudlansky in 1086, who was killed two years later by the Welsh.His cousin, Earl of Chester, Hugo d'Avranches was able to regain control of Wales, one of them at Carnarvon. It was a Norman type castle, protected by a wooden picket fence and in vyshennostyu.Vozvyshennost was later used in the construction of the stone castle Edward I.Vozmozhno, on a hill was a wooden defensive bashnya.V 1115g.valliytsy again regained their power over Gwynedd, and the castle passed into the possession of the Prince of Wales.

{dearmad_caen}Duke of Normandy \nLord of Caen
{dearmad_caen_desc}Named Duke of Normandy and ruler of Caen. \n \nDescription: \nThe first news of Caen dates from the rule of the dukes of Normandy. Throughout its history, Caen shared the fate of Normandy. At the end of IX, the Normans who had invaded northern France were exiled from Norway king Harald the Beautiful-haired-Rollon. On the seashore he vowed “that he would die or become the ruler of any land that he could conquer.” After several invasions, Rollon established himself firmly in northern Neustria, which received the name Normandy. According to the Treaty of Saint-Clair-sur-Ept, in 1909, the French king Karl Prostovaty ceded part of Neustria to him, provided that Rollo recognized himself as a vassal of the king.Rollon was baptized, married his daughter Karl and became the ancestor of the Norman dukes. The Norman influence affected long the militancy of the inhabitants Normandy and their passion for expeditions (the conquest of England and Italy, the Crusades). The beginning and end of the reign of William were for Normandy an era of unrest and war. In 1204, Normandy was conquered by Philip, it ceased to exist ak particular state and became part of the French royal domain.
{dearmad_caen_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收.  \n+1 统帅. \n+1 忠诚.

{dearmad_rennes_desc}Named the Duke of Brittany and ruler of Rennes. \n \nDescription: \nThe city of Rennes was given by the Celtic Redon tribe, who lived here in antiquity.The capital of the Redons, which gave rise to Rennes, stood at the crossroads of the main roads of the Armorica region. since IV. In the Middle Ages, the counts of Rennes disputed supremacy in Brittany at the counts of Nantes. The Duchy of Brittany was a feudal possession in northwestern France, whose lands were originally located in the historical region, and then became part of modern France in the French region of Brittany. The rulers bore the title of dukes. In 939, the Normans seized the kingdom of Brittany, on the site of which the duchy of Brittany, vassal of France, was founded.

{dearmad_paris}Lord of Paris
{dearmad_paris_desc}Named ruler of Paris. \n \nDescription: \nIn 508, the city became the capital of the Merovingian kingdom. Churches and monasteries were erected everywhere. At that time the population was about 15 thousand. On Cité towered the fortress, the residence of the king and church 权威. The basis of the city's existence was trade. Paris lost its capital function after the Franks king Hlotar II moved to Clichy, and later Charlemagne to Aachen. After the accession to the throne of the first king of France, the Capetian dynasty, Hugo Capeta, at the end of X again became the capital of the state At the end of IX, the city was raided by the Normans. In 857 they ravaged the left bank of Paris. From 885-887, the city besieged at least 40 thousand Normans in 700 ships. At the beginning of XII, the population was concentrated mainly on the fortress island of Cité. housed the episcopal palace and Notre Dame Cathedral. Hospitals for the poor functioned in churches and monasteries. On the 12th-13th, the right bank was actively populated near the port. Under King Philippe II Augustus, a new fortress wall was built on both banks of the Seine, streets were re-laid mockery. In XIII in the university formed a century earlier, four faculties operated: canon law and theology, medicine, art, philology.

The last ones built the main monuments of medieval Angers, including the castle surrounded by a moat and the hospital of John the Baptist. The city is rich in medieval monuments, among which the first place belongs to the castle of the beginning of XIII with 17 towers from 40-58 meters high.

{dearmad_bordeaux}Duke of Aquitaine \nLord of Bordeaux
{dearmad_bordeaux_desc}Named Duke of Aquitaine and ruler of Bordeaux. \n \nDescription: \nDuchy of Aquitaine is a feudal state that existed in southwestern France from the end of IX. The duchy in different historical periods included the historical regions of Aquitaine, Poitou, Auvergne, Languedoc and Gascony. The capital of the duchy is the city of Bordeaux. Agriculture, forestry, fisheries and aquaculture in general are of great importance in the economy. Aquitaine is famous for its wine. in the wine region of Bordeaux. In 877, the kingdom of Aquitaine split into two duchies-Gascony, whose lands were located south of the Garonne River. In 1058, the two duchies reunited. Subordinate to the dukes of Aquitaine and Ascones in addition to the Gascony feuds included the counties of Armagnac, Fezansac, Perigord, Poitiers, Angouleme and La March, as well as the lands of Sentong. Queen Alienora of Aquitaine, daughter of the Duke Guillaume X, was one of the most influential historical characters of medieval Europe. After the dissolution of her marriage with the king Louis VII, she in 1152, married the Duke of Normandy and the Count of Anjou, who in 1154 became king of England under the name Henry II Plantagenet.
{dearmad_bordeaux_effects_desc}\n属性：\n+5% 税收.\n+5% 贸易收入.\n+10% 法律.\n-10% 腐败.

{king_clermont}Earl of Auvergne \nRuler of Clermont
{king_clermont_desc}Named Earl of Auvergne and ruler of Clermont. \n \nDescription: \nOvergne owes its name to the powerful Gallic tribe of the Arverns, under the influence of which the lands of Languedoc and Aquitaine were influenced. A number of facts suggest that the tribe of Arverns was one of the richest tribes of the Gauls. The hilly landscape of the area contributed to the additional protection of local fortifications from the invasions of various conquerors, numerous mines for the extraction of gold, silver and precious metals, minting of their own coins and developed commodity exchange Ene with neighboring tribes. During the great migration of peoples, Auvergne fell into the hands of the Visigoths, then passed to the Franks. In VII, Aquitanian Gallo-Romans competed with the Franks for the territory of Auvergne. When the Capetian dynasty reigned, Auvergne considered herself completely independent. In X Auvergne became the subject of struggle between the counts of Poitiers and the counts of Toulouse. In 1095 a church cathedral was held in Clermont, on which Pope Urban II preached the crusade. The count of Guernes VI, who went on a trip to the East, stayed in the East until 1114. Oli French, began to intervene in the internal affairs Overni.Feodalnaya power in the Auvergne was very hard, which causes fragmentation of political power.
{king_clermont_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+1 士气. \n+1 虔诚. \n+5% 贸易收入.
¬----------------------
{iking_clermont}Emir of Auvergne \nRuler of Clermont
{iking_clermont_desc}Named Emir of Auvergne and ruler of Clermont. \n \nDescription: \nThe Auvergne owes its name to the powerful Gallic tribe of the Arverns, under the influence of which the lands of Languedoc and Aquitaine were influenced. A number of facts suggest that the tribe of Arvernes was one of the richest tribes of the Gauls. The hilly landscape of the area contributed to the additional protection of local fortifications from invasions of various conquerors, numerous mines for the extraction of gold, silver and precious metals, minting of their own coins and developed commodity Ene with neighboring tribes. During the great migration of peoples, Auvergne fell into the hands of the Visigoths, then passed to the Franks. In VII, Aquitanian Gallo-Romans competed with the Franks for the territory of Auvergne. When the Capetian dynasty reigned, Auvergne considered herself completely independent. In X Auvergne became the subject of struggle between the counts of Poitiers and the counts of Toulouse. In 1095 a church cathedral was held in Clermont, on which Pope Urban II preached the crusade. The count of Guernes VI, who went on a trip to the East, stayed in the East until 1114. French roles, starting to interfere in the internal affairs of Auvergne. The feudal power in Auvergne was very firm, which served as the reason for the fragmentation of political power.
{iking_clermont_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+1 士气. \n+1 虔诚. \n+5% 贸易收入.
¬----------------------
{oking_clermont}Strategist of Auvergne \nRuler of Clermont
{oking_clermont_desc}Named by the strategist of Auvergne and ruler of Clermont. \n \nDescription: \nThe Auvergne owes its name to the powerful Gallic tribe of the Arverns, under the influence of which the lands of Languedoc and Aquitaine were influenced. A number of facts suggest that the tribe of Arvernes was one of the richest tribes of the Gauls. The hilly landscape of the area contributed to the additional protection of local fortifications from the invasions of various conquerors, numerous mines for the extraction of gold, silver and precious metals, minting of their own coins and developed goods exchange with neighboring tribes. {dearmad_dijon}Duke of Burgundy \nLord of Dijon
{dearmad_dijon_desc}Named the Duke of Burgundy and ruler of Dijon. \n \nDescription: \nDigon from ancient times had an important military-strategic importance, since it lies at the gates of the path from the Saona and Rhone valleys to the basin between the Cole d'Or ridge and the Langres plateau. Its important position was appreciated by the Romans who laid the Castrum-Divionense here. Emperor Aurelian ordered to surround Dijon with walls up to 30 feet and 15 feet thick. In the 5th century, Dijon went to the Burgundians, and in 534 Dijon came under the rule of the Franks. In 737 Dijon was destroyed by the Saracens, and in 888 by the Normans. In 923, besieged by King Raul, son of Duke Richard V of Burgundy. In 1015, King Robert besieged Dijon and captured it; the capture of this fortress brought him all of Burgundy. In 1137, a strong fire destroyed most of Dijon. In 1183, it received city rights. Christianity was brought to these places by the martyr Venign of Dijon, who is considered the patron saint of the city.
{dearmad_dijon_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+5% 贸易收入.\n+5% 社会治安.\n+1 人民拥戴.

{dearmad_rheims}Earl of Champagne \nRheims Governor
{dearmad_rheims_desc}Named Earl of Champagne and ruler of Reims. \n \nDescription: \nBefore the Romans conquered Gaul, Champagne was inhabited by three Gallic tribes-Lingons, Senons and Remas. When Caesar arrived in Gaul as a proconsul, then Lingons and Remus the senons entered into an alliance with him and surrendered under his protection. The country underwent rapid romanization. Great roads were made, large cities began to appear on the site of military camps, built up with magnificent buildings, only in the names of some cities the traces of the tribes that once inhabited Champagne. Christianity began to spread in Champagne since II. Reims is called the “city of coronations” or the “city of kings” because, at the place where the Reims Cathedral was later built, the Apostle of Franks Saint Remigius baptized King Clovis I. Apart from the cathedral Reims's property is considered important historical sights and city facades in the Art Deco style, and the city is famous for a variety of cultural events. Charlemagne met here with Pope Leo III. In 1000. the Archbishop of Reims, Herbert of Orilliac, was elected Pope by the name of Sylvester II.

{dearmad_bruges_desc}Named the Earl of Flanders and ruler of Bruges. \n \nDescription: \nIn ancient times, Flanders was inhabited by Celtic tribes (belgi). After the conquest of Gaul Caesar belonged to the Roman province. The invasions of the Germans on Flanders began early, in the beginning of IV Saxon and tribes began to gradually populate the country from the north and from the east. The names Flanders and Flemings appeared in the Merovingian era, so the original name was only the coast of the region of Bruges. Here the beginnings of the public were already outlined and primordial flourished. The German form of the hostel-guild, with which the capitulars of the Carolingian kings tried in vain to struggle. The founding of the Flanders county by Baldwin with the Iron Hand was a direct answer to the demands of the times. The holdings of Baldwin did not occupy the whole territory of Flanders. The reign of Baldwin IV the Bearded opens a new era. little by little the military unrest, trade and industry, whose development is favored by both the geographical position of Flanders and the enterprising nature of its inhabitants, gradually subside, gradually developing, complicating urban life is underway, all kinds of connections are made between the townspeople.

{dearmad_toulouse}Count of Toulouse
{dearmad_toulouse_desc}Named Earl of Toulouse. \n \nDescription: \nDuring Roman rule, the territory, later called Languedoc, was part of the Roman province of Narbonne Gaul. Later, most of it became part of the Toulouse Kingdom of the Visigoths, whose capital was in the city of Toulouse. in the first half of VI, this territory was conquered by the Franks and became part of the Frankish kingdom. At the beginning of X, the other barons of Languedoc were in vassal dependence on the counts of Toulouse. At the same time, the counts of Toulouse successfully fought against the Normans, over whom s in 923. Raimund II, in alliance with the Duke of Aquitaine Guillaume II, won a brilliant victory. At the beginning of the Crusades, the Counts of Toulouse were the most powerful feudal lords of Southern France. Their possessions extended from the Loire to the Pyrenees and from the Garonne to the Mediterranean. As members of the highest feudal hierarchy, the Counts of Toulouse France. At the end of XII, Toulouse County reached the highest level of prosperity and culture. Raimund V was the golden age of Provencal literature. The brilliant courtyard of the Toulouse counts became the intellectual center of Europe.

{dearmad_marseille}Count of Provence \nRuler of Marseille
{dearmad_marseille_desc}Named Count of Provence and ruler of Marseille. \n \nDescription: \nIn ancient times, there were settlements of the Phoenicians, Greeks in the territory of present Provence, then, in II BC, the Romans settled here. As a result, Provence became one of the most Romanized provinces of Gaul. In III, Christianity became widespread here. After the sunset of the Roman Empire, the province was overrun by invasions of German barbarians, Visigoths and Franks. In VIII, an invasion of Arabs followed. In 855-863, there was a kingdom of Provence (King Charles of Provence), including in itself, besides Provence itself, is also a large part of Burgundy. Marseilles was revived only in the 10th century thanks to the dukes of Provence. The Crusades contributed to the growth of the commercial value of Marseille, which has since become an important transit port.

{king_lyon}Earl of Dauphine \nLion of Lyon
{king_lyon_desc}Named Earl of Dauphine and ruler of Lyon. \n \nDescription: \nВ During a general economic decline due to the invasion of barbarians and political instability, Lyon ceases to be the capital of Gaul. In 480, the Burgundians capture Lyon and the city becomes an important political and religious the center of the Kingdom of Burgundy. In 534, before the fall of the kingdom of Burgundy, Lyon loses its political importance and passes under the power of the Franks. VI and VII-city experiences constant predatory raids that devastate the dwellings of citizens. To the beginning of IX, under Charles B face, Lyon is once again experiencing a period of prosperity and regains its former importance. But the collapse of the empire brought uncertainty. The development of the city depended heavily on the church. It possessed spiritual, legal and financial power. In the Middle Ages, Lyon with the surrounding region was the county of Lyonne (fr. Lyonnais) Under Emperor Conrad II, he passes to the German Empire. The King of France condemned such a seizure. Germany and France then drew the border along the Sone River. Lyon was divided into two parts. In 1157, Emperor Frederick Barbarossa gives the Archbishop of Lyons in full control of Lyon. In 1173, the Church gained power over justice, control of customs, collection of fares through the city, the right to mint coins and gather troops.

{dearmad_genoa}Doge of the Most Holy \nRepublic of Genoa
{dearmad_genoa_desc}Named the Doge of the Holy Republic of Genoa. \n \nDescription: \nAfter the fall of the Roman Empire, the area was first captured by the Ostrogoths, in the VI Byzantines, then by the Lombards. In VIII the territory was conquered by the Franks. Transformation of Genoa into one of the largest Mediterranean ports in X , especially after the Fatimid raid, after which the townspeople, under the leadership of the bishop and local feudal ruler, built new city fortifications and strengthened ties with other Christian centers. XII Genoa becomes an independent city-state .Formally recognizing the power of the Holy Roman Emperor, Genoa was actually governed by a council of elected consuls. The peculiarity of the Genoese thalassocracy was that the influential families of Fieschi, Spinola, Doria, Grimaldi represented the trading interests of various guilds, thereby balancing each other. The city was managed as a trading the company, however, constant political discord for a long time did not interfere with its development. During the Crusades, Genoa exceeded many queens in its wealth and influence European countries with developed trade, shipbuilding industry and the banking system. The economic well-being of Genoa depended on an extensive network of colonies. Sometimes these were separate trading posts, urban suburbs, sometimes the Genoese took possession of entire islands and coasts. The penetration of the Genoese into the eastern seas was carried out both diplomatically and by direct military invasion.
{dearmad_genoa_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+10% 税收. \n+10% 贸易收入. \n+1 忠诚. \n+1 虔诚.

{idearmad_genoa}Emir of Genoa
{idearmad_genoa_desc}Named Emir of Genoa. \n \nDescription: \nAfter the fall of the Roman Empire, the area was first captured by the Ostrogoths, in the VI Byzantines, then by the Lombards. In VIII, the territory was conquered by the Franks. XII Genoa becomes an independent city-state. Formally recognizing the power of the Holy Roman Emperor, Genoa, was actually controlled by a council of elected consuls. The peculiarity of the Genoese thalassocracy was that the influential families of Fieschi, Spinola, Doria, Grimaldi represented the trading interests of various guilds, thereby balancing each other. The city was managed as a trading company, however constant political discord for a long time did not interfere with its development at all. During the time of the Crusades, Genoa surpassed many kingdoms of Europe in its wealth and influence. the whole trade, shipbuilding industry and the banking system. The economic well-being of Genoa depended on an extensive network of colonies. Sometimes it was separate trading posts, urban suburbs, sometimes the Genoese took possession of entire islands and coasts. The penetration of the Genoese into the eastern seas was carried out both diplomatically and through direct military invasion.

{odearmad_genoa}Genoa strategist
{odearmad_genoa_desc}Named Strategist of Genoa. \n \nDescription: \nAfter the fall of the Roman Empire, the area was first captured by the Ostrogoths, in the VI Byzantines, then by the Lombards. In VIII, the territory was conquered by the Franks. Transformation of Genoa into one of the largest Mediterranean ports in X, especially after the Fatimid raid, after which the townspeople, under the leadership of the bishop and local feudal ruler, built new city fortifications and strengthened ties with other Christian centers. XII Genoa becomes an independent city-state. The dominant power of the Holy Roman Emperor, Genoa was actually governed by a council of elected consuls. The peculiarity of the Genoese thalassocracy was that the influential families of Fieschi, Spinola, Doria, Grimaldi represented the trading interests of various guilds, thereby balancing each other. The city was run as a trading company, however, constant political discord for a long time did not interfere with its development at all. During the Crusades, Genoa surpassed many kingdoms of Europe in its wealth and influence, having developed trade, shipbuilding industry and the banking system. Genoa's economic well-being depended on an extensive network of colonies. Sometimes these were separate trading posts, urban suburbs, sometimes the Genoese took possession of entire islands and coasts. The penetration of the Genoese into the eastern seas was carried out both diplomatically and by direct military invasion.
{odearmad_genoa_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+10% 税收. \n+10% 贸易收入. \n+1 忠诚. \n+1 虔诚.

After the collapse of the empire of Charlemagne, the kingdom became independent, but in the middle of X it was conquered by Otton I, whose rulers have since used, in particular, the title "King of Italy." From then on, Northern Italy was an admin it is divided into three stamps, ruled first on behalf of the emperor by imperial counts, and later marquises or margraves from local noble families. Milan and Genoa joined the East Ligurian stamp, headed by representatives of Este's house since the beginning of the 11th century. Already in the 12th century, Barbarossa tried to renew the system of imperial representation in Italy by introducing a sub-stat in cities. Separation of Italy was greatly facilitated by the confrontation of emperors with the Roman popes. During this period, an independent economic policy of sowing European cities largely determined their opposition to emperors, which led to open conflicts in XII. Destroyed to the founding of Milan, however, quickly regained its strength and significance.

{dearmad_venice_desc}Named Doge of the Holy Republic of Venice. \n \nDescription: \nIn the north of Italy there lived a tribe of Venets. During the resettlement of the peoples, when the leader of the Huns Attila in 452 destroyed Aquileia, many residents sought refuge on islands in neighboring lagoons. After the fall of Western Rome the empires of the Venetian Islands, together with the rest of Italy, fell under the dominion of Odoacra, then the Ostrogoths and the Eastern Roman Empire. In the wars with the Lombards, the need for close unity and government was revealed. Spiritual and secular leaders, together with all the inhabitants, were elected Whether in 697, Paul Lucius Anafesta, the general head for his whole life, the post-Doge. The Republic, skillfully taking advantage of the favorable and safe position between the Byzantine and Frankish empires, developed its wealth and became a rich and powerful trading city. Its fleets, along with Byzantium, fought against Normans and Saracens in southern Italy. During the Crusades, Venice achieved a high degree of prosperity and extended trade ties throughout the Near and Middle East. The Grand Council was created in Venice and became the highest advisory body m of power. With the assistance of the French crusaders, Venice conquered Constantinople in 1204, reaching the highest degree of power of the republic.

The Romans organized military camps and settlements of veterans in Dalmatia. IX Dalmatian cities are part of the Croatian state. In 1000. Ragusa took the oath of allegiance to Venice in the person of Doge Pietro Orseolo. In 1081-1085 the townspeople were vassals of the Duke Robert Guiscard. Trade relations with neighboring Slavic principalities of Serbia, Bosnia and Bulgaria, in which Ragusa merchants had free trade rights and some monopolies for the extraction of minerals (primarily salt and precious metals). Beginning with the XII city, the elected prince ruled. During the same period, the city commune and communal administration bodies were formed: the Bolshoi and Maly owls Comrade With the weakening of Byzantium and the strengthening in the region of Venice, and the Normans of southern Italy, the independence of Ragusa quickly strengthened.

{dearmad_bologna_desc}Named Count | Podesta of Bologna and ruler of Emilia-Romagna. \n \nDescription: \nBologna was founded by the Etruscans around 510 BC. Bologna became a Roman colony and was decorated with many monuments. The Romans conducted the first systematic arrangement of these lands. They turned this region into a fortified base between Italy and Gaul. In the heyday of the Roman Empire, about 10,000 people lived in Bologna, it was one of the richest cities in Italy. In the Middle Ages, there was some recovery in Bologna already in V under the Bishop of Petronia, in particular , the church of St. Stephen was built. Bologna in 728, surrendered to the power of the Lombard king Luitprand. Charlemagne granted Bologna the rights of a free city. Besides standard Italian, in Bologna, its own, Bologna dialect, is quite different from it and aspirants belonging to Emiliano-Romagna narechiyu.V 1088 g.byl founded Europe's first-Studio.Dvoryanstvo University of Bologna did not carry a public service, it favored democratic system Tuscan towns before the aristocratic regime Lombard cities.

{dearmad_pisa}Count|Podesta of Pisa \nLord of Tuscany
{dearmad_pisa_desc}Named Count | Podesta of Pisa and ruler of Tuscany. \n \nDescription: \nPisan Republic became the first Italian naval power, having established its control over Corsica and Sardinia in XI-XII and established trading colonies in almost all major ports of the Mediterranean Sea. Pisa was based on intermediary trade, primarily with the Levant, Byzantium and the Spanish states. Already during the period of Byzantine and Lombard domination, the rise of maritime trade in the cities of the Italian coast began. The first power of independence and the need to organize the defense of Italy's coasts from an external threat (first by Byzantium, then by the Arabs) appeared in these cities. XI Pisa turned into an important shopping center that competes with the coastal cities of southern Italy (Amalfi, Naples, Bari) However, the main obstacle to the further development of maritime trade of the city was the incessant raids of Arabs on the Italian and South French shores. Another feature of Pisa was the close involvement of the local aristocracy in the sea kuyu trade, which explains the aristocratic character and the absence of antagonism between the nobility and the merchant in the XII elitoy.Hotya Pisa political system has been somewhat democratized, at the head of the city got elected podesta, and in the election of public officials admitted the wider trade and craft circles.

Pisa's power was based on intermediary trade, primarily with the Levant, Byzantium and the Spanish states. Already during the period of Byzantine and Lombard domination, the rise of sea trade in the cities of the Italian coast began. and the need to organize the defense of Italy's coasts from an external threat (first from Byzantium, then from the Arabs), the first elements of independence appeared in these cities. XI Pisa turned into an important shopping center that competes with the coastal cities of Southern Italy (Amalfi, Naples, Bari). However, the main obstacle to the further development of the city’s maritime trade was the incessant raids of Arabs on the Italian and South French shores. Another feature of Pisa was the close involvement of the local aristocracy in the sea torus. I say that predetermined the aristocratic nature and the absence of antagonism between the nobility and the merchant elite. Although in the XIIth century the political system of Pisa was somewhat democratized, an elected Podesta headed the city, and wider strata of trade and craft circles were allowed in the elections of state bodies.

{odearmad_pisa}Pisa strategist \nTuscany ruler
{odearmad_pisa_desc}Named the Strategist of Pisa and ruler of Tuscany. \n \nDescription: \nThe Pisa Republic became the first Italian naval power, having established its control over Corsica and Sardinia in XI-XII and established trading colonies in almost all the main ports of the Mediterranean Sea. Pisa's power was based on intermediary trade, primarily with the Levant, Byzantium and the Spanish states. Already during the period of Byzantine and Lombard domination, the rise of maritime trade of the cities of the Italian coast began. The first elements of independence appeared in these cities and the need to organize the defense of the Italian coast against an external threat (first from Byzantium, then from the Arabs). XI Pisa has become an important shopping center that competes with the coastal cities of southern Italy (Amalfi, Naples, Bari). However, the main obstacle to the further development of the city’s maritime trade was the continued raids of Arabs on the Italian and South French shores. Another feature of Pisa was the close involvement of the local aristocracy in the sea trade, which predetermined the aristocratic nature and the absence of antagonism between the nobility and the merchant elite. Although in the XIIth political system of Pisa was somewhat democratized, the elected podesta headed the city, and wider layers of trade and craft circles were allowed in the elections of state bodies.

{dearmad_rome_desc}Named Ruler of Rome. \n \nDescription: \nRome is one of the oldest cities in the world, the ancient capital of the Roman Empire. In Antiquity, Rome was often called Eternal. During the Byzantine war with the Ostrogoths, Rome was besieged six times and passed from hand to hand. hands. Over the next two centuries, when a significant part of Italy was torn away by Byzantium by the Lombards, the “Pope” began to play a leading role in the secular affairs of the city with nominal submission to the weak Byzantine Empire. With the rise of the popes, the Basilica of St. Peter and The city center moves to the Vatican Hill. Old buildings are unhindered and demolished, only those that have found shelter for Christian churches or feudal fortresses are preserved. So the Adrian mausoleum, which was advantageously located next to the Vatican Hill, became a small fortress during the construction of the walls, and eventually turned into an impregnable Papal Castle of St. Angel. Sights of Rome: Roman Forum, economic, political and religious center of ancient Rome. Imperial forums, ruins of ancient architectural post roke.Colosseum, ancient Roman amphitheater, Pantheon, ancient Roman temple of all gods.

{king_ancona_desc}Named Earl of Podesta of Ancona and ruler of Marche. \n \nDescription: \nThe city was founded by Greek colonists from Syracuse around 390 BC. In VII, the southern Slavs settled here in considerable numbers, who fought for Byzantium against the Lombards. In 774, Ancona became part of the Papal region. Around 1100, Ancona became an independent republic, which the Papal throne, the Venetian Republic and German emperors tried to take over. a collegium of six seniors stood on the head of Ancona. Ancon lawyers developed the fundamental maritime codes. In 1137,1167 and 1174, the Canonians drove away the armies of the Holy Roman Empire from their walls. The siege of 1173-1174, led by the legate of Emperor Frederick I Barbarossa, was especially cruel. Archbishop Christian Mainz

During the time of the Romans, Ancona used its own coin In VII, the southern Slavs settled here in considerable numbers, who fought for Byzantium against the Lombards. In 774, Ancona became part of the Papal Region. Around 1100, Ancona became an independent republic, which the Papal throne, the Venetian Republic, and German emperors tried to take over. Ancons were a collegium of six seniors. Ancon lawyers developed the fundamental maritime codes. In 1137,1167 and 1174, the Canonians drove away the armies of the Holy Roman Empire from their walls. Especially cruel was the siege of 1173-1174, led by the legate of Emperor Frederick I Barbarossopian and the Archbishop Mainz.
{iking_ancona_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+5% 贸易收入. \n-1 忠诚.
¬----------------------

{oking_ancona_desc}Named Ancona strategist and ruler of Marche. \n \nDescription: \nThe city was founded by Greek colonists from Syracuse around 390 BC. Greek merchants established a large purple factory here. During the time of the Romans, Ancona used its own coin In VII, the southern Slavs settled here in considerable numbers, who fought for Byzantium against the Lombards. In 774, Ancona became part of the Papal Region. Around 1100, Ancona became an independent republic, which the Papal throne, the Venetian Republic, and German emperors tried to take over. In Ancona there was a collegium of six seniors. Ancon lawyers developed fundamental maritime codes. In 1137,1167 and 1174, the Canonians drove away the armies of the Holy Roman Empire from their walls. The siege of 1173-1174, led by the legate of Emperor Frederick I Barbarossa and Christian Mainzky.

In the fortress of Castell dell Ovo in 476, was imprisoned after the overthrow of Romulus Augustulus, the last emperor Western Roman Empire. In VI Naples, the Byzantines conquered during the attempt of Emperor Justinian I to recreate the Roman Empire. In 638-1137, was the capital of the virtually independent Duchy of Naples. In 1139 it became part of the Sicilian Kingdom.

{king_bari}Duke of Bari \nApuglia Ruler
{king_bari_desc}Named Duke of Bari and ruler of Puglia. \n \nDescription: \nIn V BC, the ancient Greeks dominated here. The Romans took control of the coast during the war with Pyrrhus. Barium's fishing harbor was first mentioned in 181 BC. In 109 through the Barium, the Trayanova road branching from the Appieva and running through Brundisium, Beneventum and Kanusium passed.Brundizium accounted for the lion's share of the Roman cargo flow to Greece, Egypt and Asia Minor, the reduction of the Rome-Brundisium trade route was of great importance. one of the transit points at On the way, he received his share of economic and administrative benefits. In IX, the power over Bari belonged to the Saracens, who created the Bari emirate and laid the fortress here, which was first acquired by the Byzantines, and then in 1071 by the Normans led by Robert Guiscard. In 1096, Bari preached Peter The Hermit, under the influence of whose speeches a large party of crusaders sailed from the city to the Holy Land. In 1098 a Council was held in Bari, chaired by Pope Urban II, on the split between the Catholic and Orthodox Churches. Wilge LM Evil defeated Bari in 1156g., but Frederick II found it necessary to restore its fortifications.

{dearmad_palermo}Duke of Palermo \n Ruler of Sicily
{dearmad_palermo_desc}Named Duke of Palermo and ruler of Sicily. \n \nDescription: \nSicily was colonized by settlers from Carthage and the Greeks from the 7th century BC. During the Peloponnesian war 431-404 BC, Athens tried to capture Sicily. In 241 BC, Sicily became the first Roman province, the breadbasket of Rome. In the early Middle Ages, Sicily was in the hands of the Vandals in the 5th century AD, the Ostrogoths in VI, Byzantium from 535, the Arabs from 888 in 948 .In Sicily, a semi-independent emirate formed. In the XI Sicily, the Normans conquered, creating the Sicilian kingdom here. The conquest was accompanied by a massive influx of Romano-speaking populations from France and Italy, which led to the displacement of the Greek and Arabic languages ​​by the Sicilian language that formed here.
{dearmad_palermo_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收.\n+1 to 忠诚.\n+5% 法治.\n-5% from 腐败.

{dearmad_cagliari}Duke of Cagliari \nLord of Sardinia
{dearmad_cagliari_desc}Named the Duke of Cagliari and ruler of Sardinia. \n \nDescription: \nAt the end of VI BC, the settlement passed into the possession of the Carthaginian Republic. In 238 BC, the Romans conquered Sardinia. In the middle of V Sardinia was conquered by the Vandals. In 532, the army of Emperor Justinian annexed the island to the Eastern Roman Empire. The city received the Hellenized name Kalaris and became the residence of the Byzantine governor of Sardinia. . Four independent communities appeared on the island, from north to south Gallura, Logudoro, Arborea and Calaris. In the Middle Ages, Cagliari was located on a busy sea trade route between the Italian city-states and Arab Africa. Therefore, in the 13th century, the struggle began for the possession of this city between the Genoese and Pisa trading republics.
{dearmad_cagliari_effects_desc}\n属性：\n+5% 税收.\n-5% 社会治安.\n-1 人民拥戴.

{dearmad_pamplona}Duke of Pamplona \nLord of Navarre
{dearmad_pamplona_desc}Named the Duke of Pamplona and ruler of Navarra. \n \nDescription: \nPamplona's history began in 74 BC. e. when it was founded by the Roman commander Gnei Pompey (where the name of the city comes from). Before that, there was a small Basque settlement on the site of the city. The city was of strategic importance, being a link between the peninsula and the rest of Europe. In 446, the city was occupied by the Visigoths, and then, in the middle of the VI century, by the Franks. In the VIII century, Pamplona became the capital of the independent kingdom of Navarra. Since 738, Pamplona was ruled by the Moors - until it was conquered by the Frankish king Charles the Great, who entered into an alliance with the Basques. Pamplona flourished in the eleventh century, when the city received pilgrims traveling to Santiago de Compostela.
{dearmad_pamplona_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+1 虔诚. \n+5% 移动力.

{dearmad_zaragoza}Count of Zaragoza \n Ruler of Aragon
{dearmad_zaragoza_desc}Named Earl of Zaragoza and ruler of Aragon. \n \nDescription: \nZaragoza was founded by the Romans in 24 BC. e. under the name Colonia Caesaraugusta (Colony of Emperor Augustus), from which its current name came. In 380, a universal Christian synod took place in Zaragoza. In 712–713, the city was conquered by the Arabs. Since the VIII century, Zaragoza belonged to the Cordoban caliphate and served as a Moorish outpost in the fight against the Christian kingdoms of northern Spain. After the collapse of the caliphate, Zaragoza became the center of an independent Muslim state before it was conquered in 1118 by the king of Aragon and Navarra Alfonso I during the Reconquista and subsequently became the prosperous capital of his kingdom. By decree of Alfonso I, all the Arabs who inhabited Zaragoza were to leave the city limits. Since the end of the XII century, Zaragoza was the center of Aragon and was one of the political centers of Spain.
{dearmad_zaragoza_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+10% 税收. \n+1 残暴. \n+1 虔诚.

{dearmad_toledo}Earl of Toledo \nRuler of Castile
{dearmad_toledo_desc}Named Earl of Toledo and ruler of Castile. \n \nDescription: \nThe first permanent settlements on the territory of the city were fortresses erected during the Celtiberian era. In 192 BC, Roman Fulvius Nobilior broke the desperate resistance of the Carpet tribes living here and Outpost of Toletum. Thanks to iron ore deposits near the city, Toledo has become a significant village minting its own coins. After the first barbarian attacks, the ancient walls were fortified. In 411, the city was briefly captured by the Alans. In 418, he went over to the Visigoths and remained their capital until 711. During this time, Toledo became the center of the Catholic archbishopric. In the Middle Ages, the Toledo archbishops had their own army and took part in the Reconquista and in other military operations of the Spanish kings. The Moors conquered the Visigoths state capital in 712. The heyday of Toledo under the name Tolaitola came during their reign. Alphonse VI of Castile conquered the city on May 25, 1085. By this time, Toledo became famous for its swords and other steel products.
{dearmad_toledo_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+1 忠诚. \n+5% 法律. \n-5% 腐败. \n+1 骑士精神.

{king_barcelona}Earl of Barcelona \n Governor of Catalonia
{king_barcelona_desc}Named Earl of Barcelona and ruler of Catalonia. \n \nDescription: \nThere are two different legends regarding the founding of Barcelona. The first ascribes the foundation of the city to the hero of Greek myths Heracles 400 years before the foundation of Rome. The second legend attributes the founding of the city to Hamilcar (Amelkart) Barka to the father of Hannibal. Around 15 BC e. the Romans made a fortification from the city, the center of which was located on Mount Taber. However, its wealth and importance grew over time due to its convenient location and beautiful harbor. The city minted its own coins, some of which have survived from the time of Galba. The city grew within the walls until the Visigoths conquered it in the 5th century. At the beginning of the 8th century, the Moors conquered the city. In 801, the son of Charlemagne, Louis the Pious recaptured the city from the emir and made Barcelona the capital of the Spanish brand, a buffer zone under the control of the Count of Barcelona. Barcelona was still a Christian outpost when, in 985, it was sacked by al-Mansour. This attack gave the Count of Barcelona Borrel II an excuse to free himself from the Carolingian rule.
{king_barcelona_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+5% 贸易收入. \n+1 虔诚.
¬----------------------

The city grew within the walls until the Visigoths conquered it in the V century. At the beginning of the VIII century, the Moors conquered the city. In 801, the son of Charlemagne, Louis the Pious recaptured the city from the emir and made Barcelona the capital of the Spanish brand, a buffer zone under the control of the Count of Barcelona. Barcelona was still a Christian outpost when, in 985, it was sacked by al-Mansour. This attack gave the Count of Barcelona Borrel II an excuse to free himself from the Carolingian rule.
{oking_barcelona_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+5% 贸易收入. \n+1 虔诚.
¬------------------------------------------------- -----------------
{dearmad_leon}Duke of Leon \nLion of Leon
{dearmad_leon_desc}Named Duke and ruler of Leon. \n \nDescription: \nLeon was founded in 29 BC. e. as a camp of soldiers of the Roman VI Victorious Legion (Legio VI Victrix). By the year 74 A.D. e. was combined with the camp of the VII Paired Legion. The modern name Leon is a derivative of the Latin Legio ("legion"). The city was the headquarters of these legions in the late period of the Empire, as well as the center of the gold trade, which was mined nearby. In 540, the city was captured by the Visigoth king Leovigild, and in 717, again, this time by the Moors. However, it was one of the first cities taken again during the Reconquista, and became part of the kingdom of Asturias in 742. Subsequently, it was the capital of the kingdom of the same name. In 988, Zamora was ravaged by Muslims. After a fierce assault, Muslims broke into Leon. The Christians, led by Count Gonzalo Gonzalez, were all killed, despite courageous resistance.
{dearmad_leon_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+2 虔诚.
¬----------------------

{king_burgos}Earl of Burgos \nLord of Burgos
{king_burgos_desc}Named Earl and Ruler of Burgos. \n \nDescription: \nBurgos was founded in the 9th century (presumably in 884 AD) by King Alfonso III the Great as an important stronghold in the struggle against the Moors and rose to XI century to the city where the coronations of the Castilian kings took place. Every child in Spain knows Burgos as the city of Sida - from the vicinity of Burgos came the 11th-century Spanish national hero Rodrigo Diaz de Bivar, known by this name. Together with his wife, Dona Ximena, he is buried under the arches of the Cathedral of Burgos.
{king_burgos_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+1 忠诚. \n+1 虔诚. \n+1 士气.

{dearmad_valencia}Count of Valencia \nRuler of Valencia
{dearmad_valencia_desc}Named Earl and Ruler of Valencia. \n \nDescription: \nThe city was founded by the Romans in 138 BC. e. The heyday of ancient Valencia falls on the period of the reign of Emperor Augustus - during this period a new colony began to develop rapidly in the cultural and commercial field, which was facilitated by its location on an important trade road. In 413, Valencia was captured by the Visigoths. In 714 the Moors conquered the city, including the city as part of the Cordoba Caliphate. The beginning of the XI century is the era of the highest prosperity of the Moorish Valencia, which became the capital of the Moorish kingdom. During this period of the reign of the Moors, a network of irrigation canals was created, the city walls were rebuilt, and the city became one of the centers of Mediterranean trade. In 1094, the legendary Spanish commander Rodrigo Diaz de Vivar was able to take Valencia and free her from the Moors, after which he ruled it until his death in 1099. During his reign, Rodrigo turned Valencia from a Muslim city into one of the largest Christian centers of Spain at that time.
{dearmad_valencia_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+2 骑士精神. \n-1 忠诚.

{dearmad_granada}Count of Granada \nRuler of Granada
{dearmad_granada_desc}Named Count and ruler of Granada. \n \nDescription: \nGranada is known as the Iberian and Phoenician settlement of Iliberra from 500 BC. e. Due to the sheltered location among the surrounding mountains and very fertile land, it is assumed that villages exist here even in more ancient times. After the collapse of the Roman Empire, the region came under the influence of the North African state of the Vandals, after its collapse in 534 into several decades in the power of Byzantium. From the beginning of the 7th century it belonged to the Iberian state of the Visigoths. In 711, the city was captured by the Moors, and it began to be called in the Arabic manner - Ilbir. After the fall of the Caliphate of Cordoba in 1012, power over the city passed to the Berber lord Zavi ibn Ziri, who made Granada the residence of the Zirid dynasty, which ruled it for 80 years, turning it into one of the most prosperous states of southern Andalusia.
{dearmad_granada_effects_desc}\n属性：\n+5% 税收.\n+5% 贸易收入.\n+1 忠诚.\n+1 骑兵统帅.\n+1 个人安全. 
¬----------------------

{king_seville}Earl of Seville \nRuler of Extremadura
{king_seville_desc}Named Earl of Seville and ruler of Extremadura. \n \nDescription: \nIn the 3rd millennium BC e. on the territory of Seville the Phoenician settlement of Cefele arose. In the middle of the II century BC. e. on the site of the Phoenician settlement, the Romans founded the port city of Ispalis (Gispalis), which became a Roman colony. In 590 and 619, two large church cathedrals (concilia Hispalensia) were held here. The Arabs conquered the city in 712 and made it the capital of the province of Ishbilla, from which the modern name of Seville comes from. In 844, the city was destroyed by the Normans. After the collapse of the Cordoba caliphate, the Typha dynasty strengthened in Seville, at which time the city flourished. In 1091, the Berbers conquered Seville.
{king_seville_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 商业收入. \n+1 守城统帅.
¬----------------------

{dearmad_cordoba}Duke of Cordoba \nRuler of Andalusia
{dearmad_cordoba_desc}Named Duke of Cordoba and ruler of Andalusia. \n \nDescription: \nCordoba has been known since the Phoenician colonization. According to Strabo and Ptolemy, Cordoba is the center of the Turdetan tribe. Captured in the Second Punic War (218–201 BC) by the Romans. Under Augustus - the main city of the province of Betica. Conquered by vandals, Byzantium, Visigoths, and in 711 - by Arab troops. With 756 it was the capital of the Cordoba Emirate, and from 929 it was the Cordoba Caliphate. In the X century. reached its peak, became one of the centers of education and science, when it had up to 1 million inhabitants, many palaces, mosques, caravanserais and was the center of Arab science, poetry and art. With the collapse of the Cordoba Caliphate in 1031, Cordoba remained independent only until 1070, when it was subordinated to the Emir of Seville.
{dearmad_cordoba_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+10% 税收. \n+1 士气. \n+5% 社会治安. \n+1 人民拥戴.

{king_salamanca}Earl of Salamanca \nLord of Salamanca
{king_salamanca_desc}Named Earl and Ruler of Salamanca. \n \nDescription: \nThe city was significant already in the time of the Iberians. It is referred to as the Wakken city of Helmantica when it was captured in 217 BC. e. Hannibal. Under the Romans there was an important crossing over the Tormes River on the “Silver Road” (Via de la Plata) from Asturica Augusta to the port of Cadiz. Under the Visigoths in the 7th century, this settlement (then called Salmantica) had its own bishop. After the Arab-Berber conquest (712), the department was moved to the city of Oviedo. The Christian population succeeded the Arabs during the Reconquista of 1087-1102.
{king_salamanca_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+5% 法律. \n-5% 腐败. \n+1 忠诚. \n+1 骑士精神.

{king_murcia}Earl of Murcia \nLord of Murcia
{king_murcia_desc}Named Earl and ruler of Murcia. \n \nDescription: \nIt is widely believed that the name of the city comes from Latin. Myrtea or Murtea, meaning "land of myrtle." According to the second version, Murcia comes from Murtia, which means "the settlement of Murtius" (Murtius is a common Roman name). There is also an opinion that the name comes from lat. Murtae, Mulberry. The city on the site where Murcia is now located was founded by the Cordoban emir Abd ar-Rahman II in 825 under the name Medinat Mursiya. City planners created an extensive network of irrigation canals near Segura, which led to the expansion of the agricultural sector. In the XII century, the geographer Al-Idrisi described Murcia as a densely populated and well-fortified city. After the collapse of the Cordoba caliphate in 1031, Murcia fell into the hands of the rulers who ruled in Almeria, Toledo and Seville. After the collapse of the Almoravid state, Muhammad ibn Mardanish made Murcia the capital of an independent kingdom. During this period, Murcia became a prosperous city, famous for ceramic products that were exported to Italy. Silkworm and paper production, the first in Europe, also developed in Murcia.
{king_murcia_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+1 农业.
¬----------------------

{king_oporto}Earl of Porto \nLord Douro-Litoral
{king_oporto_desc}Named Earl of Porto and ruler of Douro-Litoral. \n \nDescription: \nPorto history begins around 300 BC. e. from the Proto-Celtic and Celtic peoples, the earliest known inhabitants of these places. Ruins of this period were discovered in several areas. In the area of ​​modern Porto, there was also a settlement of galleks. The Roman commander Decimus Junius Brutus Callaic conquered the city in about 136 BC. The Romans called the city Portus Cale. In 540, the Visigoths made the city the residence of the bishop and built a fortress. Porto came under the control of the Moors during their invasion of the Iberian Peninsula in 711. In 868, conquered by Count Vimara Pires. From 997 to 1050 again under the rule of the Moors. Since 1092, the city during the reconquest was finally liberated and part of the kingdom of Leon, as part of the county of Portucale, which is inherited by Henry of Burgundy, from which the history of independent Portugal begins in 1096.
{king_oporto_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+10% 贸易收入. \n+1 忠诚. \n+5% 社会治安. \n+1 人民拥戴.
¬----------------------
{iking_oporto}Emir Porto \nLord Douro-Litoral
{iking_oporto_desc}Named Emir Porto and ruler of Douro-Litoral. \n \nDescription: \nPorto history begins around 300 BC. e. from the Proto-Celtic and Celtic peoples, the earliest known inhabitants of these places. Ruins of this period were discovered in several areas. In the area of ​​modern Porto, there was also a settlement of galleks. The Roman commander Decimus Junius Brutus Callaic conquered the city in about 136 BC. The Romans called the city Portus Cale. In 540, the Visigoths made the city the residence of the bishop and built a fortress. Porto came under the control of the Moors during their invasion of the Iberian Peninsula in 711. In 868, conquered by Count Vimara Pires. From 997 to 1050 again under the rule of the Moors. Since 1092, the city during the reconquest was finally liberated and part of the kingdom of Leon, as part of the county of Portucale, which is inherited by Henry of Burgundy, from which the history of independent Portugal begins in 1096.
{iking_oporto_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+10% 贸易收入. \n+1 忠诚. \n+5% 社会治安. \n+1 人民拥戴.
¬----------------------

{dearmad_lisbon}Duke of Lisbon \nLuft of Lusitania
{dearmad_lisbon_desc}Named the Duke of Lisbon and ruler of Lusitania. \n \nDescription: \n During the Neolithic period, the region was inhabited by pre-Celtic tribes who erected religious and funerary monuments, megaliths, dolmens and menhirs. The Celts arrived here in the 1st millennium BC. After the victory over Carthage, the Iberian Peninsula fell under the rule of Rome. Olissipo, like most cities in the West of the empire, became the center of the spread of Christianity. After the collapse of the Roman Empire, raids of barbarians began. 711 years, Lisbon was captured by Muslims. The conquerors, mostly Berbers and Arabs erected many mosques and houses, restored the city wall and established administrative control. Islam was the official religion, Christians were allowed to live while maintaining their religion in the status of Zimmis, for which they came It was necessary to pay a special tax, however, in all other matters — property rights, debt obligations and contracting — Christians and Jews were equal with Muslims. In 1108, Lisbon was recaptured and occupied by the Norwegian crusaders led by Sigurd I on their way to the Holy. 1111 was captured by the Almoravid Moors. In 1147 during the Reconquista, the Crusaders, led by Alfonso I of Portugal, besieged and recaptured Lisbon.
{dearmad_lisbon_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+10% 税收. \n+1 忠诚.\n+5% 视野. 
¬----------------------

{dearmad_staufen}Duke of Ulm \nLord of Swabia
{dearmad_staufen_desc}Named Duke of Ulm and ruler of Swabia. \n \nDescription: \nHere there was a palace of kings from the Carolingian dynasty. In it 854 King Louis of Germany published a document in which the name of the city was first mentioned. However, the foundation of the city is usually referred to XI. During the reign of the Salic Dynasty, Ulm became the most important city of the Duchy of Swabia. From here, in December 1076, he went on his penitent trip to Canossa Henry IV in order to pray for forgiveness from Pope Gregory VII and again receive the right to be emperor. Two years later about Mr. handed over his palace along with all the duchy to his brother-in-law, Frederick I Staufen, who could take possession of it only in 1098 after a long struggle with the second anti-duke Bertold I von Reinfelden and his successor Bertold II. The kings of the Staufen dynasty intended to make Ulm an oppressor During the war for the throne with the Dynasty, the Duke Heinrich the Proud of this dynasty destroyed the city twice to the ground. Not a destroyed church, on the site of which the Ulm Cathedral was erected. When the Staufen for a long time came to power, the city began to develop rapidly.
{dearmad_staufen_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+1 残暴. \n+5% 法治. \n-5% 腐败.
