{king_oleshe}Prince of Oleshye
{king_oleshe_desc}Named Prince of Oleshye. \n \nDescription: \nIn the 10th century, at the mouth of the Dnieper, where ancient Greek colonies existed at the time of antiquity, a village was founded again, which was founded by the warriors and merchants of Kievan Rus, trading along the Byzantium along the Dnieper. Moreover, the more than 300-kilometer massif of steppes and forest-steppes between the Black Sea and the Ros River remained virtually uninhabited by the Eastern Slavs due to the constant invasions of nomadic tribes from Asia, and therefore even during the years of relative migration lull. Oleshya was of unusually important strategic importance, as it was located at the intersection of land and sea routes at the Dnieper into the Black Sea, connecting Russia through Byzantium with the Mediterranean Sea and Western Europe and around Crimea through the Sea of ​​Azov, Don and the Volga with the Caspian Sea and the Arab world. It was in Olesha that numerous ambassadors from Byzantium, the Caucasus, and Near Asia were met. In Oleshia, the Kiev princes also accepted Byzantine candidates for the Kiev metropolitan chair. Remote Oleshye was characterized by a turbulent socio-political atmosphere.
{king_oleshe_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+10% 贸易收入. \n+10% 移动力.
¬----------------------

{king_mensk}Prince of Mensk
{king_mensk_desc}Named Prince of Mensk. \n \nDescription: \nThe earliest settlements in the territory of the modern city date back to the 9th century. The Svisloch river valley was inhabited by two East Slavic tribes: Krivichi and Dregovichi. Around 980, the territory of the modern city entered the Principality of Polotsk. The first annalistic mention of Mensk is contained in The Tale of Bygone Years; it dates back to 1067, when the sons of the Kiev prince Yaroslav the Wise appeared under the walls of Mensk, then owned by the Polotsk prince Vseslav Bryachislavich. Veche refused to surrender the city, but the Yaroslavichi brothers captured and destroyed it, and then defeated the troops of Vseslav Bryachislavich who came to the aid in the battle of Nemiga. After the death of Vseslav Bryachislavich, his sons divided his father's possessions into estates, as a result of which Mensk became the capital of a separate principality. Gleb Vseslavich became the first men’s prince. The capital status and favorable geographical position contributed to the economic development of the city and its transformation into a major trade and craft center. However, frequent internecine howls the princes hindered the prosperity of the city.
{king_mensk_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+10% 税收.\n+1 忠诚 
¬----------------------

{king_polotsk}Prince of Polotsk
{king_polotsk_desc}Named Prince Polotsky. \n \nDescription: \nThe first annalistic mention of Polotsk dates back to 862. The historical core of the city was the fortified settlement of Krivichi, which appeared on the site of the ancient settlement of Bancer culture on the banks of the Polota River, not far from its mouth into the Western Dvota. The city character of the fortifications of the settlement dates back to the middle of the 10th century. In the middle of the 10th century the Principality of Polotsk arose. It occupied the territory in the basin of the Western Dvina, the upper reaches of the Berezina and Neman. In 986, the Viking missionary Torvaldo The first Christian church and monastery of St. John the Baptist on the territory of Belarus was founded by a traveler, which served as the beginning of the spread of Christianity on Belarusian lands. In 988-1001, Izyaslav Vladimirovich, the son of Rogneda Rogvolodovna and Vladimir Svyatoslavich, the founder of the Polotsk princes dynasty, reigned in Polotsk. In the middle of the 11th century, the territories of the Principality of Polotsk expanded significantly, the cities of Usvyat and Vitebsk, as well as the lands between the Western Dvina and Disna, joined. Under Vseslav Bryachislavich Polotsk to grace has reached its highest power.
{king_polotsk_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+10% 税收.
¬----------------------

The historical core of the city was the fortified Krivichi settlement, which arose at the site of the ancient settlement of Bancer culture on the banks of the Polota River, not far from its confluence with the West in the Dvota River The urban character of the fortifications of the settlement dates back no earlier than the middle of the X century. In the middle of the X century, the Principality of Polotsk arose. It occupied the territory in the basin of the Western Dvina, the upper reaches of the Berezina and Neman. {king_pskov}Prince of Pskov
{king_pskov_desc}Named Prince Pskov. \n \nDescription: \nMiddle - third quarter of the 1st millennium AD dates back to the site of the Pskov settlement, the Slavic settlement "culture of long mounds", left by migrants from the south. In the 7th-9th centuries, a kindred family existed on the site of the Pskov settlement Pskov settlement, which died in a fire in the early 860s, is the carrier of the Ryuhe culture. The end of the 9th century - the beginning of the 11th century dates back to the Pskov settlement, which is represented by wooden log buildings with plank floors on logs and someone in the corner. The area of ​​the Pskov settlement reached 12–15 hectares by the middle of the 10th century, and the population increased by 5–7 times. This indicates the appearance of immigrant immigrants in the city, including those of Scandinavian origin. The official date of foundation of Pskov is considered to be 903 - year the first mention of the city in the annals. Until the 12th century, Pskov was part of Kievan Rus. After the proclamation of the Novgorod feudal republic in 1136, the city came under the rule of Novgorod.
{king_pskov_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+1 残暴. \n+1 士气. \n-1 忠诚.

{dearmad_smolensk}Prince of Smolensk
{dearmad_smolensk_desc}Named by Prince Smolensky. \n \nDescription: \nSmolensk is one of the most ancient cities of Ancient Russia. In the dated part of the "Tale of Bygone Years" it is first mentioned under 862 as the center of the Krivichi tribal union. It is also mentioned in the Ustyuzhensky arch in the record under 863, when Askold and Dir, on a campaign from Novgorod to Constantinople, bypassed the city, as it was greatly fortified and crowded. In 882 the city was captured and annexed by Prince Oleg to Kievan Rus. After the establishment of the Principality of Smolensk in 1054, the youngest sons of Yaroslav were planted on the Smolensk table. In 1127, the Prince of Kiev, Mstislav the Great, gave Smolensk an inheritance to his 17-year-old son Rostislav Mstislavich. After the death of his father, Rostislav became virtually an independent prince and reigned in the city until 1160, when he occupied the throne of Kiev. Thus, the foundation was laid for an independent Smolensk principality, under the rule of the Rostislavich dynasty, which on the eve of the Mongol-Tatar invasion was one of the most powerful Russian principalities.
{dearmad_smolensk_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+10% 税收.
¬----------------------
{idearmad_smolensk}Khan of Smolensk
{idearmad_smolensk_desc}Named Khan of Smolensk. \n \nDescription: \nSmolensk is one of the most ancient cities of Ancient Russia. In the dated part of the "Tale of Bygone Years" it is first mentioned under 862 as the center of the Krivichi tribal union. It is also mentioned in the Ustyuzhensky arch in the record under 863, when Askold and Dir, on a campaign from Novgorod to Constantinople, bypassed the city, as it was greatly fortified and crowded. In 882 the city was captured and annexed by Prince Oleg to Kievan Rus. After the establishment of the Principality of Smolensk in 1054, the youngest sons of Yaroslav were planted on the Smolensk table. In 1127, the Prince of Kiev, Mstislav the Great, gave Smolensk an inheritance to his 17-year-old son Rostislav Mstislavich. After the death of his father, Rostislav became virtually an independent prince and reigned in the city until 1160, when he occupied the throne of Kiev. Thus, the foundation was laid for an independent Smolensk principality, under the rule of the Rostislavich dynasty, which on the eve of the Mongol-Tatar invasion was one of the most powerful Russian principalities.
{idearmad_smolensk_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+10% 税收.
¬----------------------

{dearmad_novgorod}Grand Prince of Novgorod
{dearmad_novgorod_desc}Named Prince of Lord Veliky Novgorod. \n \nDescription: \nIn the 7th century, a Slavic village appeared on the Prost river. In the first half of the 750s, Scandinavian settlements appeared in the lower reaches of Volkhov (Staraya Ladoga), but at the turn of the 760–770 years the Vikings were replaced by the Slavs. In the 9th century, at the source of the Volkhov River, on the outskirts of Slavensky hill, the settlement of Rurikovo Gorodishche already existed. Novgorod appeared around the turn of the 9th – 10th centuries or at the beginning of the 10th century]. The second most important after Kiev center of Kievan Rus, the capital of the Novgorod Republic. In the 11th century, many princes of Polotsk made raids on Novgorod. Vseslav Bryachislavich managed to capture the city in 1067. Then in Novgorod churches were looted, part of the city was burned, part of the population was taken into slavery. By the beginning of the XII century, Novgorod land included part of the Baltic states, part of Karelia, the southern part of Finland, the southern coast of Ladoga, Obonezhie, the shores of the Northern Dvina, vast expanses of the European north up to the Urals.
{dearmad_novgorod_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+5% 贸易收入. \n+5% 法治. \n-5% 腐败. \n+2 忠诚.

{king_ladoga}Prince of Ladoga
{king_ladoga_desc}Named Prince of Ladoga. \n \nDescription: \nThe settlement appeared around 753 with the advent of the Scandinavians, in the 760s the Ladoga settlement was destroyed by representatives of the early Slavic culture. The settlement was a trade center of the North of Russia. Around the 870s, the first wooden fortress was built at the confluence of the Ladozhka River in the Volkhov. In 862, the Varangians Rurik was called to reign. In 997, Eirik, the future Norwegian ruler, attacked Ladoga. The first Ladoga fortress, which existed for more than 100 years, was destroyed. The ancient Staroladozh fortress, which has become the "heart" of today's Staraya Ladoga, stands at the confluence of the Elena River in the Volkhov. In the times of Novgorod Rus, it was a strategically important place, because it was the only possible harbor where sea vessels could not stop, unable to sail along the thresholds of Volkhov.
{king_ladoga_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+5% 社会治安. \n+1 人民拥戴.\n+5% 移动力.
¬----------------------

{king_beloozero}Prince of Beloozersky
{king_beloozero_desc}Named Prince of Beloozersky. \n \nDescription: \nFirst mentioned in the "Tale of Bygone Years" in 862 as the city of Beloozero, which participated in the calling of the Vikings. "They drove the Varangian overseas, and did not give them tribute, and began to rule themselves, and there was no truth among them, and the clan stood up for the clan, and they had strife, and began to fight with each other." In 882, according to the "Tale of Bygone Years", the whole Belozersky (the ancestors of the present Vepsians) took part in the campaign of Oleg the Prophet to Smolensk and Kiev. In 1071, an uprising of smerds, instigated by the sorcerers, breaks out on Beloozero, which suppresses voivode Yan Vyshatich, collecting tribute for Prince Chernigov's Svyatoslav Yaroslavich. In the middle of the XII century, Belozersky took part in the capture of Kiev by the squads of the Grand Duke of Vladimir Andrei Bogolyubsky, and at the end of the century they participated in the campaign of the Grand Duke of Vladimir Vsevolod the Big Nest on the Volga Bulgaria.
{king_beloozero_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+5% 贸易收入.\n+10% 移动力.

{dearmad_moscow}Prince of Moscow
{dearmad_moscow_desc}Named Prince of Moscow. \n \nDescription: \nThe age of Moscow is not exactly known. Since the end of the 1st millennium AD, Slavs settled in the area of ​​modern Moscow: Vyatichi and Krivichi. Vyatichi made up the bulk of the original population of Moscow. that in the XI century there already existed a settlement, protected by a rampart and a moat, which allows it to be attributed to cities. In the XI century in Moscow there was a church, it was the Church of the Beheading of John the Baptist at the Borovitsky Gate. The first chronicle mention is the Ipatievsky annals on the heel Itza, April 4, 1147, when Rostov-Suzdal Prince Yuri Dolgoruky received his friends and allies in the town called Moscow, led by Novgorod-Seversky Prince Svyatoslav Olgovich. In the 12th century Novgorod birch bark, it is mentioned that new wooden fortifications were built here. the territory increased 3-4 times. By 1156, the chronicle attributes the foundation of the city of Moscow to Dolgoruky, among Dmitrov and other Suzdal cities, in the sense of building a wooden fortress — the future Kremlin.
{dearmad_moscow_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+1 残暴. \n-1 忠诚.\n+5% 移动力.

In the 12th century Novgorod birch bark, it was mentioned that new wooden fortifications were built here. And the total territory increased 3-4 times. {king_yaroslavl}Prince of Yaroslavl
{king_yaroslavl_desc}Named Prince of Yaroslavl. \n \nDescription: \nYaroslavl is the oldest existing city on the Volga. It was laid by Prince Yaroslav the Wise during his Rostov reign (988-1010) on the cape above Strelka at the site or near the pagan settlement Medvezhy Ugol The reference to Yaroslavl in The Tale of Bygone Years dates back to 1071. According to the annals, the Magi, headed by 300 people, went up the Volga, killing the "noble wives" along the way, and reached Beloozero, where their detachment was defeated and they were executed by the governor Jan Vyshatich. Judging by their di confused with Yan, they were not so much defenders of the ancient pagan faith as adherents of bogomilism. In 1149, the city environs were devastated by the Novgorodians, therefore, the second mention of Yaroslavl was made in the annals. In 1152, the city was besieged by the Volga Bulgars, who suddenly approached it and immediately went to it however, they didn’t succeed in taking the city at once; they had to start a siege, which was lifted by help from Rostov in time. During the first two centuries of its existence, Yaroslavl remained a small border city of Rost ovo-Suzdal, only in 1218 Yaroslavl became the capital city of the new Yaroslavl principality.
{king_yaroslavl_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n-1 忠诚.
¬----------------------

{dearmad_rostov}Prince of Rostov
{dearmad_rostov_desc}Named Prince of Rostov. \n \nDescription: \nThe first fortified settlement on Lake Nero, appeared in the land of Meri in the 7th century and has long been a Meryan tribal center. The settlement was a bastion of a pagan cult similar to the Slavic Veles, up to the XII century. They repeatedly expelled sent bishops and, according to some information, even killed them. In the IX century, Rostov, along with all the possessions of the Meryan tribe, was annexed to the state of Rurik with its capital in Ladoga. In the campaign of Prince Oleg to Constantinople, the Rostovs participated as allies: in the text of the contract between Oleg and the Greeks, they undertook to pay tribute to certain Russian cities, which included Rostov. Since the second half of the 11th century, Rostov has been one of the two main cities of the Rostov-Suzdal Principality. Until the 12th century, Rostov was divided into two parts of the Peipsi with pagan temples and Russian with the Christian church. Two people got along well with each other, in case of any threat they gathered a militia together.
{dearmad_rostov_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+1 士气. \n+10% 税收.
¬----------------------

Until the 12th century, Rostov was divided into two parts of the Peipsi with pagan temples and Russian with the Christian church. Two people got along well with each other, in case of any threat they gathered a militia together.

{dearmad_ryazan}Prince of Ryazan
{dearmad_ryazan_desc}Named Prince of Ryazan. \n \nDescription: \nSlavic tribes (namely, Vyatichi) came to Oka in the area of ​​the VI century. Already in the 7th-8th centuries around the future Ryazan a whole network of settlements was founded - settlements and settlements. The largest of them are Borkovskoye, Glebovskoye, Khrapovskoye. Arable farming was laid as the basis of the Vyatichi economy. In the VI century, Vyatichi paid tribute to the Volga Khazars. In 966, the Kiev prince Svyatoslav Igorevich defeated their powerful power and subjugated the Vyatichi, including Ryazan and Murom lands in the Kiev state. It is known that Vyatichi participated in Oleg’s famous campaigns on Constantinople. Already in the 7th-8th centuries, near Ryazan, on the Borkovsky island, a fortified trading city was located. At the beginning of the XII century, the Ryazan lands became an independent Murom-Ryazan principality. It was a time of competition between the largest cities of Ryazan and Murom for the right to be the capital of a new state. Ryazan won the battle, since it was here that the princely court was taking place, the episcopal department was located, and there were also serious fortifications.
{dearmad_ryazan_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+1 士气. \n+2 守城统帅.
¬----------------------
{idearmad_ryazan}Khan of Ryazan
{idearmad_ryazan_desc}Named Khan of Ryazan. \n \nDescription: \nSlavic tribes (namely, Vyatichi) came to Oka in the area of ​​the VI century. Already in the 7th-8th centuries around the future Ryazan a whole network of settlements was founded - settlements and settlements. The largest of them are Borkovskoye, Glebovskoye, Khrapovskoye. Arable farming was laid as the basis of the Vyatichi economy. In the VI century, Vyatichi paid tribute to the Volga Khazars. In 966, the Kiev prince Svyatoslav Igorevich defeated their powerful power and subjugated the Vyatichi, including Ryazan and Murom lands in the Kiev state. It is known that Vyatichi participated in Oleg’s famous campaigns on Constantinople. Already in the 7th-8th centuries, near Ryazan, on the Borkovsky island, a fortified trading city was located. At the beginning of the XII century, the Ryazan lands became an independent Murom-Ryazan principality. It was a time of competition between the largest cities of Ryazan and Murom for the right to be the capital of a new state. Ryazan won the battle, since it was here that the princely court was taking place, the episcopal department was located, and there were also serious fortifications.
{idearmad_ryazan_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+1 士气. \n+2 守城统帅.
¬----------------------
{odearmad_ryazan}Ryazan strategist
{odearmad_ryazan_desc}It is called the Strategist of Ryazan. \n \nDescription: \nSlavic tribes (namely, Vyatichi) came to Oka in the region of the VI century. Already in the 7th-8th centuries around the future Ryazan a whole network of settlements was founded - settlements and settlements. The largest of them are Borkovskoye, Glebovskoye, Khrapovskoye. Arable farming was laid as the basis of the Vyatichi economy. In the VI century, Vyatichi paid tribute to the Volga Khazars. In 966, the Kiev prince Svyatoslav Igorevich defeated their powerful power and subjugated the Vyatichi, including Ryazan and Murom lands in the Kiev state. It is known that Vyatichi participated in Oleg’s famous campaigns on Constantinople. Already in the 7th-8th centuries, near Ryazan, on the Borkovsky island, a fortified trading city was located. At the beginning of the XII century, the Ryazan lands became an independent Murom-Ryazan principality. It was a time of competition between the largest cities of Ryazan and Murom for the right to be the capital of a new state. Ryazan won the battle, since it was here that the princely court was taking place, the episcopal department was located, and there were also serious fortifications.

{king_susdal}Prince of Vladimir
{king_susdal_desc}Named Prince of Vladimir. \n \nDescription: \n990 year — annalistic news of the founding of the city named by Prince Vladimir Svyatoslavich on the Klyazma River. About 1108 — the construction of the fortress by Vladimir Monomakh. Vladimir begins to grow and strengthen thanks to the care of Vladimir Monom Yuri Dolgoruky, who strengthened him as a stronghold of defense of the Rostov-Suzdal principality. Yuri Dolgoruky, who lived in Suzdal at that time, kept his residence ("compound") here. The city flourished due to Prince Andrei Bogolyubsky, who at 115 On 7th year he moved the capital of the principality here. In Vladimir, the Assumption and Dmitrievsky Cathedrals were erected in Vladimir as the new capital of North-Eastern Russia. The Golden Gate became the central point of defense of the city and at the same time the symbol of the capital's status. To decorate the city, Prince Andrey spared neither money nor strength, having brought from Kiev Stone-cutters, along the perimeter of the city from the east, south and north, Silver, Copper and Irininy gates were built. In Vladimir and neighboring Suzdal, a Vladimir-Suzdal icon-painting school was formed; chronicle. The highest power of the Principality of Vladimir reaches the reign of Vsevolod the Big Nest. For the princes of Vladimir, the title of the "greats" is finally assigned, and Vladimir is the "capital city of all Russia."
{king_susdal_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+10% 税收. \n+1 农业.
¬----------------------
{iking_susdal}Khan of Vladimir
{iking_susdal_desc}Named Khan of Vladimir. \n \nDescription: \n990 year — annalistic news of the founding of the city named after Prince Vladimir Svyatoslavich on the Klyazma River. About 1108 — the construction of the fortress by Vladimir Monomakh. Vladimir begins to grow and strengthen thanks to the care of Vladimir Monomakh Yuri Dolgoruky, who strengthened it as a stronghold of the defense of the Rostov-Suzdal principality. Yuri Dolgoruky, who lived in Suzdal at that time, kept his residence ("courtyard") here. The city owed its heyday to Prince Andrei Bogolyubsky, who in 1157 he brought here the capital of the principality. In Vladimir, the Assumption and Dmitrievsky Cathedrals were erected in Vladimir as the new capital of North-Eastern Russia. The Golden Gate became the central point of defense of the city and at the same time a symbol of the status of the capital. To decorate the city, Prince Andrey spared neither money nor strength, having brought from Kiev Stone-cutters, along the perimeter of the city from the east, south and north were built Silver, Copper and Irininy gates. In Vladimir and neighboring Suzdal, a Vladimir-Suzdal icon-painting school was formed; in the city, e letopisanie.Naivysshego power of Vladimir principality reached during the reign of Vsevolod the Big Gnezdo.Za Vladimir princes finally secured the title of "Great", and for Vladimirom- "the capital city of all Russia."
{iking_susdal_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+10% 税收. \n+1 农业.

The Golden Gate became the central point of defense of the city and at the same time a symbol of the status of the capital. {king_murom}Prince of Murom
{king_murom_desc}Named Prince of Murom. \n \nDescription: \nMur was the extreme eastern outpost of Russia. It was located at the crossroads of trade routes between Russia and Bulgaria. Prince of Kiev Vladimir bequeathed to his son Gleb. According to legend, Prince Gleb received the city of Mur , made an attempt to convert its population to Christianity, but failed and was forced to escape from discontent in the fortified courtyard. Over time, Murom became more and more important as a shopping center. Bulgars repeatedly attacked Murom until it was fixed here the superiority of the Rus. Relatively long peace periods contributed to the development of crafts and trade. It is famous for its crafts: pottery, blacksmithing, bone carving, metalworking. Moore more and more strengthened his importance as a prominent Russian city on the Oka. From 1054 he became the possession of the Chernigov princes, who turned it into Chernigov princes center of the Murom-Ryazan inheritance. After the princely feuds and the congress of Russian princes in Lyubech in 1097, Murom fell into the lot of Yaroslav. The prince threatened and promises forced the Muromites to accept Christianity and baptized people .Synovya Jaroslav after the civil war divided the principality into two independent, Murom and Ryazan, which greatly weakened the position of Murom, which is why he often falls prey to the Bulgars.
{king_murom_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+5% 社会治安. \n+1 人民拥戴.
¬----------------------
{iking_murom}Khan of Murom
{iking_murom_desc}Named Khan of Murom. \n \nDescription: \nMur was the extreme eastern outpost of Russia. It was located at the crossroads of trade routes between Russia and Bulgaria. Prince Vladimir of Kiev bequeathed to his son Gleb by Mur, according to legend, Prince Gleb, having received the city of Murom , made an attempt to convert its population to Christianity, but failed and was forced to flee from discontent in the fortified courtyard. Over time, Murom became more and more important as a shopping center. Bulgars repeatedly attacked Murom until it settled the excellence of the Rus. Relatively long peace periods contributed to the development of crafts and trade. It is famous for its crafts: pottery, blacksmithing, bone carving, metalworking. Moore more and more strengthened his importance as a prominent Russian city on the Oka. From 1054 he became the possession of the Chernigov princes, which turned it into the center Murom-Ryazan inheritance. After the princely feuds and the congress of Russian princes in Lyubech in 1097, Murom fell into the lot of Yaroslav. The prince threatened and promises forced the Muromites to accept Christianity and baptized the people. ovya Jaroslav after the civil war divided the principality into two independent, Murom and Ryazan, which greatly weakened the position of Murom, which is why he often falls prey to the Bulgars.

{oking_murom}Strategist of Murom
{oking_murom_desc}Named the Strategist of Murom. \n \nDescription: \nMur was the extreme eastern outpost of Russia. It was located at the crossroads of trade routes between Russia and Bulgaria. Prince of Kiev Vladimir bequeathed to his son Gleb Murom. According to legend, Prince Gleb received the city of Murom , made an attempt to convert its population to Christianity, but failed and was forced to escape from discontent in the fortified courtyard. Over time, Murom became more and more important as a shopping center. Bulgars repeatedly attacked Murom until it fixed here the superiority of the Rus. Relatively long peace periods contributed to the development of crafts and trade. It is famous for its crafts: pottery, blacksmithing, bone carving, metalworking. Moore more and more strengthened his importance as a prominent Russian city on the Oka. From 1054 he became the possession of the Chernigov princes, who turned it into Chernigov princes center of the Murom-Ryazan inheritance. After the princely feuds and the congress of Russian princes in Lyubech in 1097, Murom fell into the lot of Yaroslav. The prince threatened and promises forced the Muromites to accept Christianity and baptized people After the internecine war, the village of Sons of Yaroslav divided the principality into two independent ones - Murom and Ryazan, which greatly weakened the position of Murom, because of which he more than once became the prey of the Bulgars.
{oking_murom_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+5% 社会治安. \n+1 人民拥戴.

{king_narovchat}Prince of Narovchat
{king_narovchat_desc}Named the ruler of Narovchat. \n \nDescription: \nMordovian settlements appeared in the 4th-3rd century BC. In the XII century, on the Moksha River, the Narovchatsky fortified settlement appears, like the Burtass fortress - an outpost in Mordovian lands. As new lands are developed, the settlement turns into a full-fledged city - the economic and administrative center of the Upper Primokshan. The fortifications of the Narovchatsky settlement, now known as the "hillocks", were built in the late XII - early XIII centuries.
{king_narovchat_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+1 农业. \n+10% 移动力.
¬----------------------

{king_sharukan}Prince of Sharukan
{king_sharukan_desc}Named Prince Sharukansky. \n \nDescription: \nPresumably the city of Sharukan appeared on the basis of the Alans settlement, had a mixed population and was a winter refuge of the Polovtsy. The city consisted of a relatively small number of stone buildings and a much larger number of nomad yurts. In 1111 and 1116, Sharukan was captured by the troops of Vladimir Vsevolodovich Monomakh and other princes. From ancient manuscripts it is known that the battle of 1111 began due to the clash of the opposing forces of the hunters. Sharukani’s men violated the bans that were unbreakable under Vladimir Vsevolodovich Monomakh and were severely punished for this. The exact dates of the battle for Sharukan are unknown, but, according to the surviving chronicles, it did not last long. In the XII - early XIII centuries, Sharukan was desolate and fell into decay.
{king_sharukan_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+10% 移动力.
¬----------------------

{king_azaq}Prince of Azak
{king_azaq_desc}Named Prince of Azak. \n \nDescription: \nThe first Scythian settlements appeared about 2 thousand years ago. During the Scythian era, many settlements arose in the Northern Azov region, which subsequently played an important role in the development and establishment of the region, for example, the Tanais Bosporus colony. Also in the territory of present Azov there were two Greco-Meotian settlements, which were called Paniardis and Patarva. Due to its favorable position, extensive trade has developed here. Already in the 6-8 centuries, Iranian-speaking nomads were replaced by numerous Turkic tribes, and later by the Huns, Bulgarians, Avars, Khazars. In the 10th century, after the defeat of the Khazars in Russia, the Tymutarakan principality and the Khazar fortress Sarkel became a Russian city called Belaya Vezha, The Sea of ​​Azov increased flow of the Slavic population. And in 1067 the city was subjugated by the Polovtsy and became known as Azov.
{king_azaq_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 贸易收入. \n+15% 移动力.\n+1 骑兵统帅. 
¬----------------------

{king_tmutarakan}Prince of Tmutarakan
{king_tmutarakan_desc}Named Prince of Tmutarakan. \n \nDescription: \nThe city was founded by the Greeks from the island of Lesbos. In the 6th century, the Bosporus became a federation or part of the Byzantine Empire of Justinian I. In the 6th century, the city was conquered by the Turkic Kaganate and since that time received the new name Tumen-Tarkhan. Soon after the collapse of the Turkic Kaganate, Tumentarkhan became Khazar and is sometimes referred to as Samkerts in the sources of the 9th-10th centuries. . At this time, under the influence of raids, he turned into a fortress. The population of the city was multi-ethnic. Greeks, Armenians, Khazars, Alans settled here. The religious situation was also variegated: Christianity coexisted with Judaism and Tengrianism. The bulk of the population was engaged in trade. After the defeat of the Khazar Khaganate in 965 by the Kiev prince Svyatoslav Igorevich, the city came under the rule of Russia. Through Tmutarakan, economic and political ties were maintained between the Russian principalities, the peoples of the North Caucasus and Byzantium. Greeks, Alans, Khazars, Slavs and Armenians continued to live in the city. After 1094, references to Tmutarakan disappear from Russian chronicles.
{king_tmutarakan_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+1 虔诚.
¬----------------------

{king_khlynov}Prince of Vyatka
{king_khlynov_desc}Named Prince of the Vyatka Land. \n \nDescription: \nIn the first half of the 1st millennium AD, the Finno-Ugric tribes of the Udmurts (in the eastern part) and the Mari (in the western part) are formed in the basin of the Vyatka, in the north of the basin - tribes Komi. At the end of the XII - the beginning of the XIII centuries, the settlement of Vyatka land with the first Russian immigrants began; they founded the first Russian cities Nikulitsyn, Kotelnich, Khlynov on the banks of the Vyatka. With the beginning of the Mongol-Tatar yoke, the influx of immigrants sharply increased.
{king_khlynov_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收.\n+10% 移动力.

{king_kazan}Prince of Kazan
{king_kazan_desc}Named Prince of Kazan. \n \nDescription: \nKazan was founded in 1004-1005. as a border outpost on the northern borders of the Volga Bulgaria. Ancient Kazan appears in the form of a small, but rather strongly fortified fortress, with powerful stone walls with a base width of about 1.8 - 2 m, made of untreated limestone “dry” or using clay-limestone mortar. Kazan is experiencing growth, becoming an important trade and political center. The favorable geographical position at the intersection of major trade routes connecting East and West contributes to the growth of the city.
{king_kazan_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+10% 移动力.\n+1 残暴.

{oking_kazan}Strategist of Kazan
{oking_kazan_desc}Named Strategist of Kazan. \n \nDescription: \nKazan was founded in 1004-1005. as a border outpost on the northern borders of the Volga Bulgaria. Ancient Kazan appears in the form of a small, but rather strongly fortified fortress, with powerful stone walls with a base width of about 1.8 - 2 m, made of untreated limestone “dry” or using clay-limestone mortar. Kazan is experiencing growth, becoming an important trade and political center. The favorable geographical position at the intersection of major trade routes connecting East and West contributes to the growth of the city.
{oking_kazan_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+10% 移动力.\n+1 残暴. 
¬------------------------------------------------- -----------------
{dearmad_bulgar}Prince of Bulgaria
{dearmad_bulgar_desc}Named Prince of Bulgaria. \n \nDescription: \nThe city was founded in the 10th century by the Bulgars, Turkic-speaking tribes living in the Volga region. At first it was a small fortification, later it grew to the size of a city. The high coast at the confluence of the Kama River in the Volga created excellent conditions for the overview of the surrounding area and river navigation. In a short time he became the largest center of trade in his region. Soon after its foundation, Islam became the main religion of the Bulgars. In its heyday, the town was considered one of the centers of handicraft. Many skilled artisans, jewelers, blacksmiths and tailors lived in it.
{dearmad_bulgar_effects_desc}\n属性：\n+5% 税收.\n+1 统帅.\n+1 士气.\n+1 残暴.\n+15% 移动力.\n+1 忠诚. 
¬----------------------

{king_yelabuga}Prince of Yelabuga
{king_yelabuga_desc}Named Prince Elabuzhsky. \n \nDescription: \nThe exact date of foundation of Elabuga is unknown, the settlement was built by the Bulgars at the turn of the X-XI centuries, at the site of the winter crossing the Kama River. In the Bulgarian period, the settlement became an integral part of the trade-caravan road from the central regions of the Volga Bulgaria to the Middle and Upper Prikamye and further to the Arctic Ocean. In the XII century. A white-stone mosque-castle (Ak-mosque) with eight towers and half towers was built.
{king_yelabuga_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+1 守城统帅. \n+5% 移动力.

{king_jaiksk}Prince of Saray
{king_jaiksk_desc}Named the Prince of Sarai. \n \nDescription: \nThe ancient city of Sarai Batu, the capital of the Golden Horde, was founded by Batu Khan in 1250. In the beginning, it was a nomad's rate, which eventually grew into a city. Sarai Batu was the main political center of the Golden Horde, but the economic center probably did not immediately. The first coins were issued here about 30 years after the foundation. About 75 thousand people lived in Saray-Batu. The population was multinational: the Mongols, Kipchaks, Alans, Circassians, Russians, Bulgars, Byzantines lived here. Each ethnic group settled in its quarter, where there was everything necessary for life: school, church, bazaar, cemetery. In the city there were quarters of artisans: potters, jewelers, glass blowers, bone cutters, masters in smelting and metal processing.
{king_jaiksk_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+1 骑兵统帅.

{king_embi}Prince of Yaika
{king_embi_desc}Named Prince of Yaik. \n \nDescription: \nYaik located in the center of the Eurasian steppes, goes back to the Neolithic era. In the 1st millennium BC, during the heyday of nomadic cattle breeding, Yaik was associated with the Savromato - Sarmatian tribes that lived here. The first fortified settlements were erected by the Sarmatian-Alanian and Oguz-Pecheneg tribes. In 1219-1221 the steppes were invaded by the Mongol invaders led by Genghis Khan. The area has become an integral part of the state of the Golden Horde.
{king_embi_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+1% 移动力.

{king_astrakhan}Prince of Saksin
{king_astrakhan_desc}Named Prince of Saksin. \n \nDescription: \nItil is the capital of the Khazar Haganate in the middle of the VIII-X centuries. The name literally translates as "Big River". Woznik on the site of a winter road as a Khan’s headquarters. In sources IX, the city appears under the name Hamlidge (Hamlykh), which can be understood as a Khan's city. The name Itil appears in the 10th century. Itil was a multinational and religiously diverse city inhabited by Jews, Christians, Muslims, shamanists and pagans, many of whom were merchants from other countries. the needs of each faith There were religious temples: churches, mosques and synagogues. The city had about 30 quarterly mosques with schools and one cathedral mosque with a minaret. To resolve disputes, there were seven judges: two for Jews, Muslims and Christians, and one for all pagans. 968 / In 969, Itil was taken by the Kiev prince Svyatoslav Igorevich and completely destroyed. For some time the city was under occupation, and the Khazar ruler lived in exile on the coast in the possession of Khorezm. After the departure of the Rus, the royal court was able to return. According to al-Biruni, in the 11th century, Itilezhal in razvalinah.V XII-early XIII century in the Lower Volga there was a large city Saxin.
{king_astrakhan_effects_desc}\n属性：\n+5% 税收.\n+5% 贸易收入.\n+1 忠诚.\n+5% 社会治安.\n+1 人民拥戴.

{iking_astrakhan}Khan of Saksin
{iking_astrakhan_desc}Named Khan Saksin. \n \nDescription: \nItil is the capital of the Khazar Haganate in the middle of the VIII-X centuries. The name literally translates as "Big River". Woznik on the site of a winter road as a Khan’s headquarters. In sources IX the city appears under the name Hamlidge (Hamlykh), which can be understood as a Khan's city. The name Itil appears in the 10th century. Itil was a multinational and religiously diverse city inhabited by Jews, Christians, Muslims, shamanists and pagans, many of whom were merchants from other countries. the needs of every denomination oval religious churches: churches, mosques and synagogues. The city had about 30 quarterly mosques with schools and one cathedral mosque with a minaret. To resolve disputes, there were seven judges: two for Jews, Muslims and Christians, and one for all pagans. In 968 / In 969, Itil was taken by the Kiev prince Svyatoslav Igorevich and completely destroyed. For some time the city was under occupation, and the Khazar ruler lived in exile on the coast in the possession of Khorezm. After the departure of the Rus, the royal court was able to return. According to al-Biruni, in the 11th century, Itil lying down l in ruins. In the XII — beginning of the XIII century in the Lower Volga region there was a large city Saksin.

{dearmad_sarkel}Prince of White Vezha
{dearmad_sarkel_desc}Named the Prince of the White Vezha. \n \nDescription: \nSarkel Fortress (literally "the white house") was built between 834 and 837 on the Don River. At the request of the rulers of Khazaria, who turned to the Byzantine emperor Theophilus, the construction was carried out with the mediation of Byzantine engineers. Sarkel became the main outpost on the northwestern border of the Khazars. It was based on a regularly replaced garrison of three hundred soldiers. The city on the trade route became a busy shopping center. The fortress and city of Sarkela were captured by Kievan Rus under Prince Svyatoslav I in 965. The city was renamed the White Vezha and populated by the Slavs. He remained Slavic until the XII century. In 1103, Vladimir Monomakh took with him to Russia the Pechenegs and Torques. They formed the garrison of the White Vezha until the Polovtsy ravaged the city in 1117 and it was abandoned by the inhabitants.
{dearmad_sarkel_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+10% 移动力.
¬----------------------

In 943, the famous Arab chronicler Al-Masoudi first reported the city. During its heyday, about 15 thousand inhabitants lived in the city. The Great Silk Road passed through Magas, providing the city with wealth and prosperity.

{dearmad_tbilisi}Prince of Tiflis \nLord of Georgia
{dearmad_tbilisi_desc}Was named Eristavi of Tbilisi and ruler of Georgia. \n \nDescription: \nIn 853 Tbilisi was captured by Arab forces led by Bug-Turk. In 914, the emir Abul-Kasim invades southern and eastern Georgia. In 979, with the help of David Kuropalat, an uprising was crushed Varda Sklira against Basil II. In 1008–1010, King Bagrat III created the Single Georgian State by annexing Kakheti and Ereti in 1010. In 1023, a peace treaty was signed between Georgia and Byzantium, and the Byzantines attacked Georgia again in 1028. In 1064 and 1068 two campaigns of the Seljuks on Gro In 1073, the feudal lords revolted against George II. In 1083, George II began to pay tribute to the Seljuks, in 1099 David IV the Builder stopped paying tribute. In 1104, David IV the Builder convenes the Ruiz-Urbnis Cathedral, and in 1106 construction of the Gelati Monastery began. 1110 from the Seljuk Turks were liberated by Samsvilda, in 1115 — Rustavi, in 1117 — Gishi, in 1118 — Laura was freed from the Seljuk Turks. On August 12, 1121 the Seljuk army was defeated by Georgians in the Battle of Didgor, later Tbilisi was liberated from the Seljuk Turks in 1122, in 1123 — Dmanisi.
{dearmad_tbilisi_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+10% 贸易收入. \n-1 忠诚. \n-0.5% 拥挤.

{king_kutaisi}Prince of Kutaisi \nRuler of Imeretia
{king_kutaisi_desc}Named Prince Kutaisi and ruler of Imereti. \n \nDescription: \nKutaisi was founded in the 6-5th centuries. BC .. The history of Kutaisi begins in the II century BC. The Byzantine historian Procopius of Caesarea (VI century) in the book “The war with the Goths” (book 4, section 14), describes Kutaisi in this area: “There are many populated villages in this area This is the best of all the lands of Colchis. Wine is produced here and many good fruits are grown, which is not found anywhere else in the rest of Lazik. A river named Rion flows through this country. From here the Eet proceeded and set off, and as a result the poets call him Koytay, and the Colchian land of Koytaida. Very close to Kutais is very strong a new fortification called Ufimery; he was guarded with his garrison by the manhole with all care. In ancient times, according to many ancient historians and writers, including the ones mentioned above, Kutaisi was the capital of the Colchis kingdom, that is, kolkhs - ancient Georgians. From VIII to XIII centuries Kutaisi was the capital of the Abkhazian Kingdom.
{king_kutaisi_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+5% 贸易收入. \n+1 个人安全. 
¬----------------------

{oking_kutaisi}Strategist Kutaisi \nRuler of Imeretia
{oking_kutaisi_desc}It is called the Strategist of Kutaisi and the ruler of Imereti. \n \nDescription: \nKutaisi was founded in the 6-5th centuries. BC .. The history of Kutaisi begins in the II century BC. The Byzantine historian Procopius of Caesarea (VI century) in the book “The war with the Goths” (book 4, section 14), describes Kutaisi in this area: “There are many populated villages in this area This is the best of all the lands of Colchis. Wine is produced here and many good fruits are grown, which is not found anywhere else in the rest of Lazik. A river named Rion flows through this country. From here the Eet proceeded and set off, and as a result the poets call him Koytay, and the Colchian land of Koytaida. Very close to Kutais is very strong a new fortification called Ufimery; he was guarded with his garrison by the manhole with all care. In ancient times, according to many ancient historians and writers, including the ones mentioned above, Kutaisi was the capital of the Colchis kingdom, that is, kolkhs - ancient Georgians. From VIII to XIII centuries Kutaisi was the capital of the Abkhazian Kingdom.
{oking_kutaisi_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+5% 贸易收入. \n+1 个人安全. 
¬------------------------------------------------- -----------------
{king_baku}Prince of Baku \nRuler of Shirvan
{king_baku_desc}Named Prince of Baku and ruler of Shirvan. \n \nDescription: \nFrom the Middle Ages, Baku was located in the historical region of Shirvan, north of the region of Azerbaijan. From the second half of the 9th century, Baku became part of the Shirvanshahs. The population was engaged in crafts, trade, fishing, horticulture and oil production. Until the 11th century, the beginning of Turkization, the population of Baku continued to speak the language of indigenous peoples. In the XII century, Baku was surrounded by a two-row fortress wall and a moat. The Maiden’s Tower also entered the city’s defense system.
{king_baku_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n-1 忠诚.\n+5% 社会治安.\n+1 人民拥戴.

{dearmad_yerevan}Prince of Yerevan \nRuler of Armenia
{dearmad_yerevan_desc}Named Prince of Yerevan and ruler of Armenia. \n \nDescription: \nThe earliest mention of the city refers to the year 607, when a certain Daniil from Yerevan was mentioned among the Armenian churchmen who remained faithful to the decisions of the Chalcedon Cathedral. Yerevan was one of the settlements in the zone Persian-Byzantine wars in Armenia in the 7th century, mentioned in connection with the Arab conquest: in August 650 it was besieged by Arabs, but to no avail. The city fell under Arab rule in 658. In 660 there was an anti-Arab uprising. With the fall of Arab power and the restoration of the Armenian statehood city was part of the Kingdom of Ani Bagratuni; in the XI century it was conquered by the Seljuks. The city was localized in the historical region of Kotayk, of the XIII century “Kotayk is the city of Yerevan with its own region”.

{king_ankara}Prince of Ankara
{king_ankara_desc}Named Prince of Ankara. \n \nDescription: \nAnkara is one of the oldest cities in Asia Minor. Known since the 7th century BC under the Greek name Angor or Ankir (Ἄγκυρα, "anchor"), located at the intersection of busy trade routes connecting Europe and Asia. In the late Byzantine period, a large number of wealthy Greek families lived in the city. In 1071, after the defeat of the Byzantine army at the Battle of Manzikert, Ankara came under the control of the Seljuks, although there was no total destruction of Christians here. beat off the Turks had knights participating in the 1st Crusade, but after their departure the Turks again occupied the city. In 1118 the Byzantines managed to temporarily regain control of Angira, but in 1176 they lost it again forever. At the end of the XII century Orthodoxy in the city quickly fell into decay .
{king_ankara_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+5% 贸易收入. \n+10% 移动力.

It is considered the birthplace of St. Paraskeva-Friday (III century). the time of the Roman emperor Claudius, the city was handed over to the veterans and received the name "Claudiconium." The city belonged to the Roman province of Lycaonia, in Greek times the city belonged to Phrygia. It is evident from the imperial coins that Iconium had the rights of the Roman colony. Iconium is especially often mentioned in the era of the Crusades. Konya District in the 1070s took herring uki.The power of the Seljuk state was gradually weakening, while Iconium was the capital, the state was called the Iconic Sultanate, and the name Konya appeared a couple of centuries later.Konya was an active center of both Turkish and Persian culture. During the Seljuk period, the famous poet and mathematician Omar Khayyam (1048–1131). In the XIII century Mevlana Jalaleddin Rumi lived and was buried here, here in 1244 he met with Shems Tabrizi, and they formed the Sufi order of Mevlevi.

{dearmad_caesarea}Prince of Caesarea
{dearmad_caesarea_desc}Named Prince of Caesarea. \n \nDescription: \n In ancient times, it was known as Caesarea of ​​Cappadocia, Caesarea, Mazak and Eusebius. It was the residence of the Cappadocian kings. Then, after the conversion of Cappadocia to the Roman province, it was renamed Cesecari of Tiberi Roman coins in Asia. It was the center of the spread of Christianity. After the division of Cappadocia into provinces under the emperor Valens, Caesarea became the capital. In the 4th century the local pulpit was occupied by St. Basil the Great. Arab general (and later the first caliph Umayyadov) Mu Avia invaded Cappadocia and temporarily took Caesarea from the Byzantines in 647. The city was called Caesarea by the Arabs, and later Kayseri by the Seljuk Turks, when it was captured by the Alps Arslan in 1067. The forces of the latter destroyed the city and destroyed its population. In 1074–1178 The area came under the control of the Danishmendids and was restored in 1134. The Anatolian sultanate controlled the city during 1178–1243. The city came under the rule of the Ottoman Empire in 1515. 
{dearmad_caesarea_effects_desc}\n属性：\n+10% 税收.\n+2 进攻统帅.\n+2 忠诚.\n+10% 移动力.

{king_sinop}Prince of Sinope
{king_sinop_desc}Named the Prince of Sinope. \n \nDescription: \nSinope is in ancient times one of the main Greek colonies on the southern coast of Pontus of Euxinus, on the peninsula of the Paflagona coast, east of Cape Karambis. The colony was founded, according to legend, by the companion of Jason Autolik, which had a temple and an oracle here. Under Mithridates Yevpator, who was born and educated here, Sinop became the residence of the Pontic king and was decorated with magnificent buildings. Statues of Autolycus were then taken to Rome between other works of art by Lucullus. a vigorous and autonomous city, Sinop was colonized by the Romans in 45 BC. Sinop trade was famous for Cinnabar. As it ascended in IV AD, the role and welfare of Sinop began to decline. According to the Crusader Charter 1204 on the division of the Byzantine Empire, Sinop was nominally included in the Latin Empire, but in fact it was never controlled. From 1205 he belonged to the Trebizond Empire, but on November 1, 1214 he took the Seljuk Sultan with his cunning, immediately turning all the Greek churches into mosques. Having conquered the city, the Turks knocked out to Sinop st citadel manifesto to locals in Greek.
{king_sinop_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+5% 贸易收入. \n-1 忠诚.
¬----------------------

{king_diyarbakir}Prince of Diyarbakir
{king_diyarbakir_desc}Named Prince Diyarbakir. \n \nDescription: \nHistorical name of this ancient city is Amida or Amed. In IV, by the order of Constantius II, city walls of basalt hewn stones were erected around it. In 359, Amid was conquered by the Iranian Shah Shahap Shahap Shaap. Subsequently, Justinian I conquered the city and carried out additional fortification works. Then Amid again passed into Iranian hands. In 640 he was conquered by the Arab tribe Bekir (or Bekr), in his honor was named Diyarbekir. Diyarbekir was one of the points of the Great Silk Road. In 958 visa Ntians regained control of the city. In 1001, Diyarbekir became the residence of the Kurdish dynasty of the Mervanids. In 1085 it passed into Turkmen hands.

{dearmad_mosul}Prince of Mosul
{dearmad_mosul_desc}Named Prince of Mosul. \n \nDescription: \nThe city passed into hands with the rise of the Sassanids in 225. In the second century, Christianity began to spread among the Assyrian population of Mosul. It became the bishop's residence of the Nestorians in VI. 637, during the Caliph Urim al-Khattaba, the city was annexed to the Righteous Caliphate. Mosul received the status of the capital of Mesopotamia under the Umayyads in VIII, when it reached the peak of prosperity. During the time of the Abbasids, the city was an important trading center due to its strategic location on the trade routes to India , Persia, and the Mediterranean. At the end of IX, control of the city was taken by General Abbasid Ishaq ibn Kundai, but in 893 Mosul came under the direct control of the Abbasids. In X Mosul came under the authority of the local Arab dynasty of the Hamdanids. From Mosul Hamdanides under Abdullahan ibn Ibn the son of Nasir al-Daul expanded their control over Jazira for the next several decades, first as governors of the Abbasids, and later as de facto independent rulers. A century later they were supplanted by the Ukaylids. In XI, Mosul was conquered by the Seljuks. During the reign of the semi-independent Atabeks in 1127, it became the center of the Zangid dynasty.
{dearmad_mosul_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+5% 贸易收入.
¬----------------------
{idearmad_mosul}Caliph of Mosul
{idearmad_mosul_desc}Named by Khalif Mosul. \n \nDescription: \nThe city passed into the hands of the Sassanids in 225. In the second century, Christianity spread among the Assyrian population of Mosul. It became the episcopal residence of the Nestorians in VI. 637, during the Khalifa al-Khattaba, the city was annexed to the Righteous Caliphate. Mosul received the status of the capital of Mesopotamia under the Umayyads in VIII, when it reached the peak of prosperity. During the time of the Abbasids, the city was an important trading center due to its strategic location on the trade routes to the Indus Yu, Persia, and the Mediterranean Sea. At the end of IX, control of the city was taken by General Abbasid Ishaq ibn Kundai, but in 893 Mosul came under the direct control of the Abbasids. In X Mosul came under the rule of the local Arab dynasty of the Hamdanids. From Mosul Hamdanides under Abdullahan ibn his son Nasir al-Daul expanded their control over Jazira for the next several decades, first as governors of the Abbasids and later as de facto independent rulers. A century later they were supplanted by the Ukaylids. In XI, Mosul was conquered by the Seljuks. follows the reign of the semi-independent Atabeks in 1127 it became the center zengid dynasty dynasty.

During the time of the Abbasids, the city was an important trading center due to its strategic location on the trade routes in I diya, Persia, and the Mediterranean. At the end of IX, control of the city was taken by General Abbasid Ishaq ibn Kundai, but in 893 Mosul came under the direct control of the Abbasids. In X Mosul came under the authority of the local Arab dynasty of the Hamdanids. From Mosul Hamdanides under Abdallahan ibn his son Nasir al-Daul expanded their control over Jazira for the next several decades, first as governors of the Abbasids and later as de facto independent rulers. A century later they were supplanted by the Ukaylids. In XI, Mosul was conquered by the Seljuks. .After the reign of the semi-independent Atabeks in 1127, it became the center of the Zangid dynasty.
{odearmad_mosul_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+5% 贸易收入.
¬------------------------------------------------- -----------------

IV century — Tabriz, at that time a small area, was destroyed as a result of the Armenian-Persian war. The end of the 9th century — the emirate of the Sajjid was formed after the onslaught of the Arab Caliphate. XII — XIII century — the capital of the State of Ildehyzids.

{dearmad_baghdad}Prince of Baghdad
{dearmad_baghdad_desc}Named Prince of Baghdad. \n \nDescription: \nBaghdad was founded on the west bank of the Tigris River on July 30, 762. The construction of this city, originally the capital of the state of the Abbasids, began by order of the caliph Abu Jafar al-Mansur. After the seizure of power in the Arab Khalifa The Abbasids decided to move the capital from Damascus east, closer to Khorasan, which served as the stronghold of their supporters. The new capital was closer to the geographic center of the caliphate, which significantly expanded its eastern borders in VII – VIII. In IX – X, Baghdad turned into a major cultural and the center of the Middle Eastern territories. Craft and trade with other countries developed rapidly and successfully. Baghdad received various products and expensive goods from Arabia, India and Europe. Documents drawn up by the Arab scholar Ibn-Khordadbeh in IX mentioned the trade relations of Baghdad with merchants ar-Rus. During the reign of the Abbasids (VIII-XIII). After the collapse of the state of the Abbasids, the political and administrative role of the city fell significantly, but cultural significance remained important for all Arab countries. Baghdad quickly acquired a stat a major research center: in the beginning of XIII 30bibliotek.V opened more than 945 city became part Buyid dynasty to 1055 was on the territory of the Seljuks.

{idearmad_baghdad}Caliph of Baghdad
{idearmad_baghdad_desc}Named by Khalifa of Baghdad. \n \nDescription: \nBaghdad was founded on the western bank of the Tigris River on July 30, 762. The construction of this city, originally the capital of the state of the Abbasids, began by order of the caliph Abu Jafar al-Mansur. After the seizure of power in the Arab The Abbasids decided to move the capital from Damascus east, closer to Khorasan, which served as the stronghold of their supporters. The new capital was closer to the geographic center of the caliphate, which significantly expanded its eastern borders in VII – VIII. In IX – X, Baghdad turned into a large cultural and economic center of the Middle East territories. Craft and trade with other countries developed rapidly and successfully. Baghdad received various products and expensive goods from Arabia, India and Europe. Documents drawn up by the Arab scholar Ibn-Khordadbeh in IX mentioned trade relations of Baghdad with merchants ar-Rus. During the reign of the Abbasids (VIII-XIII). After the collapse of the state of the Abbasids, the political and administrative role of the city fell significantly, but cultural significance remained important for all Arab countries. Baghdad quickly acquired a hundred the tus of a major scientific center: at the beginning of the XIII more than 30 libraries were opened. In 945, the city became part of the Buid dynasty, from 1055 it was in the territory of the Seljuk state.

Baghdad quickly gained from the status of a major scientific center: at the beginning of the XIII century more than 30 libraries were opened. In 945, the city became part of the Buid dynasty, from 1055 it was located in the territory of the Seljuk state.

{king_basra}Prince of Basra
{king_basra_desc}Named Prince of Basra. \n \nDescription: \nIn VIII-IX, Basra became one of the most important cultural and economic centers of the Caliphate. The city was born by the Arabian universal scientist Ibn al-Khaysam, writer and theologian Al-Jahiz and the Sufi mystic Rabia al-Adawiya. In 869 a rebellion of zinjas — black slaves — broke out and in 871 the zinjs plundered Basra. In 923, a radical Muslim sect invaded the city and devastated it. From 945-1055, Baghdad and most of Iraq were ruled by the Buid dynasty. Abu al-Qasim al-Baridis who controlled Basra and B Asit, was defeated, and its lands in 947 also came under Buid rule. In the mid-900s, the Basid governor of Basra was Sanad al-Daul al-Khabashi, who built a library of 15,000 books. In 1122, the Seljuk military commander Imad al-Din Zangi received Basra as a feudal possession. At the same time, the Great Friday Mosque was built in the city. In 1126, Zengi suppressed the rebellion of the townspeople. The founder of the Assassin sect, Rashid ad-Din Sinan ("old man of the mountain") was born in Basra between 1131 and 1135.
{king_basra_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+1 骑士精神.\n+5% 法治.\n-5% 腐败.

{king_ahvaz}Prince of Ahwaz
{king_ahvaz_desc}Named Prince Ahwaz. \n \nDescription: \nAhwas, the once-winter residence of the Persian kings, lies south of the ancient capital of Shushter, on the left bank of the Karuna River, which flows under the Basra into the connected Tigris and Euphrates. This place is built of stones made of stones taken from the ruins of the ancient city near which it is located. They were engaged in crushing cane sugar, which was brought here in large quantities. On one of the barrows there is a huge pillar built of plates and bricks painted in different colors; the Arabs call it Qasr, i.e. castle. Ancient Ahvaz was the main city of the same name provintsii.Sluzhil residence of the last Parthian king Artabanus IV. Mani appeared here under the monarchy as the founder of Manichaeism. In the fourth residence of the Nestorian bishop, he was transferred from here to Gondisapor. Under the rule of the Arabs, Ahwas flourished, was famous for his trade and for all of West Asia served as the main folding place for sugar trade.
{king_ahvaz_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+1 农业.

{king_kermanshah_desc}Named Prince of Kermanshah. \n \nDescription: \nIn the 11th century, Kermanshah became a major cultural and commercial center in western Iran and the southern Kurdish populated areas in general. In the 12th century, the local population in the region began to be called "Kurds" - but not as an ethnic group, but as a social group that kept the traditions of Iranian nomads along with religious zeal. Often falling under the influence of the Kurdish nobility, the rulers lost loyalty to the central government and became local leaders.

{king_isfahan}Prince of Isfahan
{king_isfahan_desc}Named Prince of Isfahan. \n \nDescription: \nThe ancient Isfahan was part of the Elamite empire. Under the name of Aspandan, it became one of the main cities of the Medes when the Iranian Medes settled there. Subsequently, the province became part of the Achaemenid Empire, and after the liberation of Iran from Macedon by the forces of Arshakids — part of the Parthian kingdom. Pahan was the center of a vast province ruled by Arshakid rulers. Under the Sassanids, Spahan was ruled by members of seven noble Iranian families who held high court posts. Moreover, during this period, Spahan was an important military center with powerful defensive structures. Many Jews and Christians lived in the vicinity of the city. After the final defeat of Iran, the Arabs captured the city. Esfahan, like other cities of Iran, fell under the rule of the Arabs until the Abbasid era. X under the Buids, Isfahan regains its significance. Under the Sultan Melik Shah, Isfahan became the capital of the Seljuk state. In XI, the famous Persian philosopher Avicenna lived and taught in Isfahan.
{king_isfahan_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+5% 贸易收入.

{king_ray}Prince of Ray
{king_ray_desc}Named the Prince of Ray. \n \nDescription: \nRay is one of the oldest cities in Iran. The city was one of the centers of the Medes, and then the states of the Achaemenids, Seleucids and Sassanids, and was called Arsakia, which translates as white Saki - a Scythian tribe. Seleucus Nikator restored the city after the earthquake that happened during his reign and gave the city the name of Europe. During the Parthian wars, it was almost completely devastated and bloodless, later Arshak restored it again. In 1227, Jalal ad-Din defeated a Mongol detachment near Ray. Rei retained its significance in Muslim times.
{king_ray_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+1 虔诚.

{king_shiraz}Prince of Shiraz
{king_shiraz_desc}Named Prince Shiraz. \n \nDescription: \nShiraz, the stronghold of the regional power of the Arabs in Fars, grows as an administrative center. In 869, the Turkic Saffarid dynasty comes to power. However, the Arab and Turkic population get used to the Persian culture. In 870. a Jami mosque is being built. Shiraz becomes the capital of the Buid dynasty and becomes a major cultural center of the East. The Buids defeat the Baghdad caliphs and Shiraz gains international importance. Literature, science, and art are developing. Religious minorities are also flourishing. An underground canal from the mountains, which provided the city with clean water. In 1000, the Seljuks attack Shiraz, they are supported by supporters of the remaining caliphate in the war against the Buids. The war lasts 50 years, civil war breaks out between the Buids and the city is destroyed. In 1062, the Seljuks occupied Shiraz, however the conquerors during the struggle adopted the Persian culture and began to patronize and maintain traditions. They built a great empire. Split in the Seljuk army, the Turks from the Salgurid clan seized power, they strengthened in Shiraz and rely on Persian traditsii.Vosstanovlena wall around the city with eight vorotami.V 1110g.Hanafity take power in their hands at least regione.Tem Shiraz thrives tolerance, religion feel svobodno.V Shiraz settle Turks and kavkaztsy.Stroyatsya temples, flourishing law and order.
{king_shiraz_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收.
¬----------------------
{iking_shiraz}Lord of Shiraz
{iking_shiraz_desc}Named the Ruler of Shiraz. \n \nDescription: \nShiraz is the stronghold of the regional power of the Arabs in Fars, growing as an administrative center. In 869, the Türkic Saffarid dynasty comes to power. However, the Arab and Turkic population get used to the Persian culture. In 870. a Jami mosque is being built. Shiraz becomes the capital of the Buid dynasty and becomes a major cultural center of the East. The Buids defeat the Baghdad caliphs and Shiraz gains international significance. Literature, science, and art develop. Religious minorities also flourish. In 950 an underground canal from the mountains was provided, which provided the city with clean water. In 1000, the Seljuks attack Shiraz, they are supported by supporters of the remaining caliphate in the war against the Buids. The war lasts 50 years, civil war erupts between the Buids and the city is destroyed. In 1062, the Seljuks occupied Shiraz, however the conquerors during the struggle adopted the Persian culture and began to patronize and maintain traditions. They built a great empire. Split in the Seljuk army, the Turks from the Salgurid clan seized power, they strengthened in Shiraz and rely on the Persian ideological traditions. The wall around the city with eight gates was restored. In 1110, Hanafites took control of the region. Nevertheless, tolerance flourishes in Shiraz, religions feel free. Turks and Caucasians settle in Shiraz. Temples are built, law and order flourish .
{iking_shiraz_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收.
¬----------------------

{oking_shiraz_desc}Named the Strategist of Shiraz. \n \nDescription: \nShiraz, the stronghold of the regional power of the Arabs in Fars, grows as an administrative center. In 869, the Turkic Saffarid dynasty comes to power. However, the Arab and Turkic population get used to the Persian culture. In 870. the Jami mosque is being built. The war lasts 50 years, civil war breaks out between the Buids and the city is destroyed. {king_yazd}Prince of Yazd
{king_yazd_desc}Named Prince of Yazd. \n \nDescription: \nMemories of the city appeared as far back as 3000 BC. It was designated as the city of Isatis in Media. Here the rules of the Achaemenid dynasty. Yazd, far from the historical capitals, was able to avoid brutal destruction. The city has many architectural monuments and cultural relics of ancient times. It was a thriving city with developed silk production. The Mausoleum of Dovazdeh-Imam (11th century) was built. During the invasion of Genghis Khan, artists, scientists and poets were able to escape from persecution here.

{king_damghan}Prince of Damgan
{king_damghan_desc}Named the Prince of Damgan. \n \nDescription: \nThe name Damgan is derived from “Deh” and “Mogan.” “Deh” means a village, and “Mogan” means a magi. This name was given by Zoroastrians, among whom were people such as King Cyrus and Darius of ancient Persia. It was founded by Damgan Khushang, the great-grandson of Keymars and the founder of the legendary Pishdadida dynasty. Until the 1st century AD, Damgan was the capital of this great province. During the invasion Alexander the Great in Iran, the Greeks called him Hecatompylos (“one hundred gates”). Damgan was half destroyed during the earthquake in 856. Damgan was an important city in the Middle Ages and was the capital of the province of Kumis (Kumes). Here, the Tari Khan mosque was built. Damgan shines like a bezel in the desert egione.S its rich cultural heritage and the true origin of the ancient civilization of Damghan is undeniable, and each relic in the city can confirm their true past, wiping the dust of oblivion with this shiny rims.
{king_damghan_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+1 统帅. \n+1 生命. 
¬----------------------

{king_gorgan}Prince of Gorgan
{king_gorgan_desc}Named the Prince of Gorgan. \n \nDescription: \nDuring the reign of Cyrus the Great in 559-530 BC, Gorgan was included in the Persian Empire. Under Darius I was part of the satrapy of Hyrcania. Alexander of Macedon conquered Hyrcania, but was wounded in battle, after which his vision deteriorated. After the fall of the Empire, Alexander Gorgan became a part of the Seleucid Empire. In III BC, the north-eastern nomads belonging to the Parn tribe invaded Parthia and Hyrcania. If the first was lost forever, then the second was temporarily won by the Seleucid ruler Ant Joach III the Great in 209 BCE For the Parthians, the new name for the guys, Hyrcania was an important part of the Empire, located between the territory of Parthia and their native steppe lands. It was there that their summer residence was located and it was they who built the Great Gorgan wall. In IX Russian when merchants traveled to the Caspian countries, they reached Gorgan, from where they sometimes sent their goods to camel to Baghdad. In 935-1090, emirs from the Persian Ziyarid dynasty ruled in Gorgan. The most supreme power over Gorgan in the X century belonged to Sam nidam then Bouida.
{king_gorgan_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+1 农业.

{king_mashhad}Prince of Mashhad
{king_mashhad_desc}Named Prince Mashhad. \n \nDescription: \n Throughout its history, Mashhad has been an important political, cultural and religious center. In 818, in the village of Sanabad, near Tusa, the 8th Shiite imam Ali bin Musa ar-Reed (Persian - Imam Reza), son-in-law of caliph al-Mamun, suddenly died. According to legend, he was poisoned by the son of the most popular of the Baghdad caliphs Harun ar-Rashid. The place of martyrdom (in Arabic - Mashhad) Reza among Muslims is very revered, especially among Shiites. The Mausoleum of Imam Reza was later built on the site of the tomb. Later, the village of Sinabad, during the destruction of the city of Tus, began to grow and develop, turning into the city of Mashhad. For the first time the word "Mashhad" as the name of the city was used in the X century by the geographer al-Mukaddasi. Mashhad is a holy Shia city. It houses the Mausoleum of Imam Reza.
{king_mashhad_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+5% 贸易收入.

{king_khiva}Prince of Khiva
{king_khiva_desc}Named the Prince of Khiva. \n \nDescription: \nKhiva was founded more than 2500 years ago. In ancient times, the city was known as Heyvak. According to the tradition of Khiva, it was founded by one of the prophets. In its history, the city survived the Achaemenid conquest and the heyday when the borders of ancient Khorezm extended to Colchis. From 305-995 Khorezm, which included Khiva, was ruled by the Afrigid dynasty. In 712, Khiva was captured by the Arabs. After that, Khiva became part of the Muslim world. Despite the dependence on the Arabs, the Afigids retained power until the end of X. In 995-1017 The odes of Khorezm were ruled by the Mamunid dynasty. In the 11th century, Khiva became dependent on the Seljukids. In 1097 the Anushteginids dynasty came to power. In the 9th-12th centuries, besides many Islamic educational institutions, large centers of science successfully operated in Khorezm: astronomy, mathematics, medicine, chemistry etc. The “House of Wisdom", actually the academy of sciences created by the then ruler Al-Mamun in Baghdad, was led by Muhammad al-Khwarizmi, a native of Khorezm. Already in IX his fundamental works on mathematics, geography, and geodesy were known in Europe Huge science Noah left the legacy of Al-Biruni, Najmuddin Kubra and other scientists and theologians whose names are also associated with Khorezm.
{king_khiva_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+5% 法律. \n-5% 腐败.

{king_urgench}Prince of Urgench
{king_urgench_desc}Named the Prince of Urgench. \n \nDescription: \nOne of the largest cities of the Great Silk Road. It is mentioned in the holy book of the Zoroastrians Avesta under the name "Urva." In the Kangyu period, the city is known as "Hangird", "Hajird." In 305 -995 years, Urgench as part of the state led by the Afrigid dynasty. After the Arab expansion, it was called Gurganj. In X on the right bank of the Amu Darya, the Afigids ruled under the Samanids. This was the origin of the North Khorezm state Urgench emirate, the capital of which this city was. It was second only to Bukhara in size. In 995, the emir Mamun ibn Muhammad defeated South Khorezm, killing the last Afrigide Abu Abdullah Muhammad. Having united the whole region under his authority, he began to rule from the south-Khorezm capital Kyatazm. .With the rise of the new Khorezm dynasty of Anushteginids, descended from the Turkmen tribe of Bekdili (Begdili), the city returns its capital status and under Alauddin Muhammad turns out to be the center of a huge empire in Central Asia and the Middle East .XII and early XIII were the heyday of Urgench is superior in terms of population and fame all the cities of Central Asia, in addition to Bukhara. He gives shelter to Avicenna, Al-Biruni, Ibn Battut and other famous thinkers of that time.
{king_urgench_effects_desc}\n属性： \n+5% 税收. \n+5% 社会治安. \n+1 人民拥戴.\n+2 残暴.

{iking_urgench}Lord of Urgench
{iking_urgench_desc}Named Lord of Urgench. \n \nDescription: \nOne of the largest cities of the Great Silk Road. It is mentioned in the holy book of the Zoroastrians Avesta under the name “Urva.” In the Kangyu period, the city is known as “Hangird”, “Hajird.” In 305 -995 years Urgench as part of a state led by the Afrigid dynasty. After the Arab expansion, it is called Gurganj. In X on the right bank of the Amu Darya, the Afigids ruled under the Samanids. This was the origin of the North Khorezm state Urgench emirate, the capital of which was In the Samanid Empire, it was second only to Bukhara in size. In 995, the emir Mamun Ibn Muhammad defeated South Khorezm, killing the last Afrigide Abu Abdullah Muhammad. By uniting the whole region under his authority, he began to rule from the south Khorezm capital of 7 Khat. conquered by Mahmud Ghaznevi. With the rise of the new Khorezm dynasty of Anushteginids, descended from the Turkmen tribe of Bekdili (Begdili), the city returns its capital status and under Alauddin Muhammad turns out to be the center of a huge empire in Central Asia and Middle East Ostok. XII and the beginning of XIII were the heyday of Urgench, surpassing all the cities of Central Asia in population and fame, except Bukhara. He gives shelter to Avicenna, Al-Biruni, Ibn Battut and other famous thinkers of that time.

In 995, the emir Mamun ibn-Muhammad defeated South Khorezm, killing the last Afrigide Abu-Abdallah Muhammad. By uniting the whole region under his authority, he began to rule from the south-Khorezm capital of Khat. conquered by Mahmud Ghaznevi. With the rise of the new Khorezm dynasty of Anushteginids, descended from the Turkmen tribe of Bekdili (Begdili), the city regains its capital status and under Alauddin Muhammad turns out to be the center of a huge empire in Central Asia and Middle East current. XII and the beginning of XIII were the heyday of Urgench, surpassing all the cities of Central Asia in terms of population and fame, except Bukhara. He gives shelter to Avicenna, Al-Biruni, Ibn Battut and other famous thinkers of that time.

{dearmad_jerusalem}Ruler of Jerusalem
{dearmad_jerusalem_desc}Named Ruler of Jerusalem(Judea). \n \nDescription: \nThe kingdom was created after the capture of Jerusalem by the crusaders in 1099. Gottfried of Bouillon, one of the leaders of the First Crusade, was elected the first king. He refused to accept this title, not wanting to wear the royal crown where the Savior wore a crown of thorns; instead, he accepted the title (“Protector of the Holy Sepulcher.”) Godfried died the following year, his brother and heir Baldwin I was not so pious and immediately accepted the title “King of Jerusalem.” Baldwin successfully expanded the kingdom, capturing the port cities of Acre, Sidon and Beirut, and also asserting its dominion over the crusader states in the North - the county of Edessa, the Principality of Antioch and the county of Tripoli. During it, the number of Latins who came with the Rear Guard Crusade increased, and also Latin appeared Patriarch. Italian city-states (Venice, Pisa and Genoa) began to play an important role in the kingdom. Around 1040 in Jerusalem, the Order of the Johannites (Hospitallers) founded a hospital for pilgrims. Another monastic order is the Templar. -obosnovalsya in the temple that has been converted from the Al-Aksa.Novoe generation born and raised in the Levant, considered the Holy Land as their homeland and a negative attitude to the newly coming krestonostsam.Takzhe they were often more like the Syrians, and not on the franc.
{dearmad_jerusalem_effects_desc}\n属性：\n+15% 税收.\n+2 进攻统帅.\n+2 虔诚.\n-2 忠诚.

{idearmad_jerusalem}Ruler of Jerusalem
{idearmad_jerusalem_desc}Named Ruler of Jerusalem(Judea). \n \nDescription: \nThe kingdom was created after the capture of Jerusalem by the crusaders in 1099. Gottfried of Bouillon, one of the leaders of the First Crusade, was elected the first king. He refused to accept this title, not wanting to wear the royal crown where the Savior wore a crown of thorns; instead, he accepted the title (“Protector of the Holy Sepulcher.”) Godfried died the following year, his brother and heir Baldwin I was not so pious, and immediately adopted the title “King of Jerusalem.” Baldwin successfully expanded the kingdom, capturing the port cities of Acre, Sidon and Beirut, and also asserting its dominion over the crusader states in the North - the county of Edessa, the Principality of Antioch and the county of Tripoli. During it, the number of Latins who came with the Rear Guard Crusade increased, and also Latin appeared Patriarch. Italian city-states (Venice, Pisa and Genoa) began to play an important role in the kingdom. Around 1040 in Jerusalem, the Order of the Johannites (Hospitallers) founded a hospital for pilgrims. Another monastic order is the Templar. You — settled in a temple converted from the Al-Aqsa Mosque. The new generation, born and raised in the Levant, considered the Holy Land their homeland and negatively related to newcomers to the crusaders. They also often looked more like Syrians rather than Franks.
{idearmad_jerusalem_effects_desc}\n属性：\n+15% 税收.\n+2 进攻统帅.\n+2 虔诚.\n-2 忠诚.
